author: {'steamid': '76561198043909546', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1237, 'last_played': 1708846761}
review:
Okay, I hopped into this game thinking it was going to be another Terraria with an RPG twist.....I was wrong. 

This is not a boss rush game, this is an RPG.  The game gave me about 20 hours of gameplay, but I'm sure if you did all the side quests and a bit of crafting for your house you could get 30~ hours easily.  

My main gripe with the game is that on the open world you can dig as far deep as you want, but instead of finding rarer ore, more dangerous monsters, and new biomes, you find the same copy paste enemies with a chest.  You are region locked so no matter how much you explore the open tiles you will not find anything new until you progress.  

The gameplay loop of terraria was farm new ore, build new armor/weapons/tools, kill boss.  Repeat.

You could farm new ore on each region for upgrades but its painfully slow, and if you just find secret chests and kill bosses, you are rewarded with equal or sometimes BETTER gear than the region locked ore.  

Once I realized this I stopped crafting all together, this game is not a terraria clone at all.  The game rewards you with free crafting levels from scrolls that monsters drop, so randomly killing mobs is incentivised more than actually crafting items.  

You can skip entire acts of this game by grinding 10 pieces of a map in the open world, meaning you can skip literal hours of content in about 15 minutes of each new zone.  I skipped the snow region, and the main city region entirely.  

It's a bit sad that you can exploit like this but you are encouraged to do so.  I farmed Iron ore for about 2-3 hours in the Act 3 to gear myself up to steel armor/weapons, only to replace most of the gear in next 15 minutes of questing.  

TLDR:  This is not a terraria clone at all, it is an RPG but a fun one that will give you 20-30 hours of gameplay

author: {'steamid': '76561197986237645', 'num_games_owned': 496, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 169, 'last_played': 1708586932}

I feel like I got played. https://steamcommunity.com/app/490280/discussions/0/4142816719801689412/

author: {'steamid': '76561197970583863', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 18413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14619, 'last_played': 1710521951}
review:
This game like Crea does a very good job of blending RPG with the Survival craft genre. The RPG side of it makes it replayable since there are many skill trees and some of the skills have interesting development plus race traits that give significant bonuses.

Crafting is well done , you unlock new stuff as you get better from crafting. Armour crafting is interesting as it comes with stat modifiers that will make significant differences where you can stay in battle longer and also help with skills making them more spamable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035922163', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 627, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 590, 'last_played': 1705708459}
review:
As many others have said this is a great concept and I can't wait to see what they do with the second one. However, I probably would not pick this up yet if you are buying it because they are coming out with a remake apparently that will fix some issues with the new engine they are using for the sequel. Unless on mega sale. 

I think this game's fun factor really depends on what choices you make. It offers freedom of choosing what race and abilities you'd like to play, but I feel like some are just inherently more fun than others. 

For example, I played as a Goblin who just wanted to use a dagger (rogue type) and become a trader. However, there is no dual wielding and you are at a severe disadvantage in combat against other enemies. I imagine a necromancer or someone wielding a giant axe and not caring about farming is prob easier and as a result more fun. 

I really liked the profession system because I liked it in elder scrolls. However, dang is it slow...chopping a tree or mining is so slow. Also, digging in sand should not be the same as mining hard rock. 

TLDR; I love the concept and it's a great idea. I am eagerly waiting for the sequel and remake to pick it up again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049595053', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 4860, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4860, 'last_played': 1704098355}

review: I honestly really enjoyed the game, there is a lot to do, and craft. i nearly have all of the achievements, save three, the first one is getting to level fifty i think, i could get that one, it would not take long. but to complete the other two i have to finish my last side quest, i think i needed to give someone a few books. but, i always throw them out after reading them, and i can not get them back! i searched all levels, but i still could not find them. the game is good, but i don't want to replay the entire game for a few books. i can't wait for part two! the biggest thing that bothers me is that enemy with melee attack can be dodged by walking behind them, so you will almost never get hit. otherwise i like the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037960452', 'num_games_owned': 3958, 'num_reviews': 423, 'playtime_forever': 1997, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1997, 'last_played': 1704652833}
review:
Простая, но приятная двухмерная линейная РПГ с элементами песочницы. Рекомендую по скидке!
Качественная пиксельная графика с множеством изображений врагов и предметов, простенькая боевая система (ближний бой, магия и призыв существ), большой мир и элементы песочницы (возможность строить на несюжетных локациях) за небольшую цену.
Из минусов стоит отметить репетативность боевой системы и прокачки, отсутствие карты и некоторую несбалансированность (оружие в тайниках обычно хуже того, что можно создать самому; некоторые этапы прогрессии экипировки проще пропустить; прокачка на поздних уровнях скатывается в гринд или фарм).
Надеюсь, что следующая игра серии станет только лучше!

author: {'steamid': '76561198072622990', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 1837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1837, 'last_played': 1704570292}
review:
Pas de possibilité de mettre un avis neutre ce sera négatif du coup.
95% des gens ne font pas plus de la moitié du jeu (la moitié c'est en gros 30h de jeu si on fait 100% à chaque zone).
Je l'ai trouvé lassant. Les mécaniques du jeu ne sont pas suffisamment satisfaisantes.
Toute fois au vu du prix, c'est rentable.. Mais j'arrête par lassitude et c'est embêtant.
Trop de quête inintéressante mais pire que tout : des aller retour continuel pour les quêtes, et même une quête a elle seule peut vous demander de faire des va et vient nullisime. Ce que je supporte le moins.
Jeu moyen, ça aurait pu être bien pire, mais ça aurait pu être bien mieux aussi. 
J'ai préféré Terraria et Starbound où j'ai + de 100h sur chacun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198228877744', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1704164919}
review: After just over an hour and a half of playing, I'm somewhat disappointed and disinclined to continue. The idea of the game is good, but the plot failed to grip me, the crafting and fighting feel pretty generic, and I'm experiencing some kind of bug with saving where the game sometimes just randomly returns me to an earlier save and deletes any other progress that I've made. This is frustrating, to say the least. But honestly I'm not having enough fun with the game to justify working on solving whatever is causing the problem. The devs had a neat idea and I don't mean to knock their hard work; this one just didn't do it for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998950879', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2865, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1830, 'last_played': 1704366077}
review:
While I am still in the process of playing through the game I can recommend this for any player who enjoys a Terraria, Core Keeper, or Stardew Valley type experience.  It does have some issues with bugs and unimplemented features that will not be fixed by the developers as they are now focused on their newest projects so go in with that in mind.

It is worth picking up on sale and the game is good enough that I suggest picking it up to support the devs while they work on their next projects!

author: {'steamid': '76561197971226175', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 5659, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5659, 'last_played': 1703195644}
review:
It's as if Skyrim and Terraria had a baby, to a limited extent.  The game is [i]okay[/i], but it's not [i]great[/i].  Here's what I think after playing it through:
[h1]The plot is linear, short, and generic[/h1]
Don't expect great writing, and the characters won't really engage your interest - there's no depth to them, certainly nothing that affected the story outcomes.
[h1]The crafting is grindy and goes nowhere[/h1]
Tying character progression to levelling up skills is a novel approach, but the skills don't do anything much except for fuelling character levels.  The building and farming aspects of this game aren't interesting enough for me to want to play in the endgame after defeating the Big Bad Boss - like the writing, there just isn't the depth to keep my interest.  For example, there's no use for the starting materials after you reach the next tier of crafting - when you get to that stage, then it's just back off to gathering a new set of materials.  It might have been nice to have fewer blueprints to unlock, but being able to upgrade quality by using the new materials in crafting them...  But I digress.
[h1]There's not much to the landscapes[/h1]
Comparing RoM's terrains to Terraria's is unfair given the amount of dev-time and polish that have gone into Terraria's biome generation, but the majority of the map has no points of interest to make it worth exploring - unless you're gathering seeds or minerals.    There are extra hand-crafted dungeons to bash around in, but only a few.
[h1]No mods[/h1]
Mods would have given the game a [b]lot[/b] more legs - a quest-editor would let people create and share content to keep the game interesting after the storyline is over, even if a more complicated modding API were out of the question.
[h1]Lightweight, hassle-free combat[/h1]
I got this game to relax with after work, so I didn't need it to provide huge doses of adrenaline.  As long as you play intelligently, you can win without needing the reflexes of a cat.
[h1]Cool music, though[/h1]
RoM definitely harks back to Skyrim, and the music often sounded like a pastiche of Skyrim themes to me.  I liked it.
[h1]Overall[/h1]
You can have some fun with this game, but in my opinion the golden children of the genre are still Terraria and Starbound - and they're about the same price.  I'd definitely give RoM 2 a look if it came out, but you're likely to get more value for your money out of at least those two competitors.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080435169', 'num_games_owned': 1908, 'num_reviews': 277, 'playtime_forever': 287, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 287, 'last_played': 1702850610}
review:

combat is nice tho , just wish this was an actual sandbox with rpg elements

+ Devs abandoned the game and didnt add things they promised to add and are working on their next games which i wont be buying cuz i feel like i got scammed in this already , cant ask for a refund anymore cuz i got this  months ago full price and couldnt get any time to play it until recently ...rip

author: {'steamid': '76561198012215097', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 2929, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2445, 'last_played': 1703975684}
review: I was surprised at how much I enjoyed this game. I bought it with rather low expectations... but the game-play and story were pretty meaty, and I found myself constantly looking for the next task. I would love to see this game get the kind of love Terraria, No Man's Sky and Cyberpunk 2077 got... which is to say more content, details, things to fight, and places to explore. Still, for a $10 game, it is certainly worth the purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082407705', 'num_games_owned': 286, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1702005454}
review: Premissa interessante, porém extremamente mal otimizado, combate terrivelmente lento, exploração meia-boca, quests nem um pouco interessantes e foco infinito em grind. Depois de anos, lançaram um update que supostamente resolve muitos problemas, mas, na realidade, foi só uma desculpa para divulgarem um remaster desse mesmo jogo e um anúncio sobre o desenvolvimento da continuação dele. Sinceramente, não tenho mais interesse em apoiar essa desenvolvedora.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016948399', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1944, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1853, 'last_played': 1701684459}
review: Nice little game. Decent quests. Nice implementation of the over-world with the Terraria-styled maps you can travel to. Building is enjoyable and the combat, while simple, is still fun and functional. I'm also enjoying the progression with loot and character skills.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057384714', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 803, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 803, 'last_played': 1701483812}
review:
I thought this would be right up my alley, but I just couldn't get into it. The combat is not very challenging, the quests are incredibly simplistic and linear, and the other activities, like crafting, just feel like a grind to fill in time.

It's not all bad, however. The lore they set up was at least mildly interesting. It just wasn't enough to carry the rest of the game. Also, it looks like they've committed themselves to releasing a remake/remaster of this game on the same engine they plan to use for Realms of Magic 2. I think it will be worth checking out to see if that helps with at least the criticism I had for combat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045536238', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2467, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1072, 'last_played': 1701727469}
review:
Pros

Feels like starbound, the world is incredible big and lets you explore new areas and towns, however as far as I have come the underground biomes feels a little lackluster and repetitive.


Detailed and rich character creation, and each race have thier own pros and cons.
However I dont understand the purpose of the gnomes and that they only have negative traits. I get the idea that they are suppose to be a challenge to play. However i feels its more than enough to simply increase the difficulty, but thats just my own preference.


Cons

Having the ability to put your talent points into everything at some point. Some may see this as an upside I however dont like it, it destroys the RPG element and replayability to create new characters and build a personal connection to your character by having thier own speciality rather than being good at everything.

The combat is stiff and not very interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049484831', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 986, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 986, 'last_played': 1662660410}
review:
Habe dieses Spiel nun seit einer ganzen Weile und auch die Entwicklung in diversen Stadien miterleben dürfen und kann nur sagen, das es wirklich ein schönes Spiel ist, was mir persönlich viel Freude bereitet. 
Wenn man Spiele, wie Terraria oder Starbound mag, sollte man sich dieses Spiel durchaus gönnen und sich von der Welt und der Spielemechanik in den Bann ziehen lassen.
Kann dieses Spiel daher nur weiter empfehlen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002541970', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1055, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 571, 'last_played': 1703045402}
review:
Giving this a thumbs up more because I like the foundation or the vision they had for the game. Hopefully their 2nd game is able to push all these core concepts further and refine them.

Ultimately, I fell for the Splattercat meme because he can make mediocre games come off a bit more appealing than they actually are. The game has awesome ambition and premise; I genuinely feel like this kind of terraria/starbound thing could be great in a more grandiose RPG-styled setting.

But at the end of the day, the combat is pretty meh and unrefined, half the skills are pretty nice but overall most of the skill trees feel a bit shallow and unfinished, weapon variety, enemy variety, fetch quests--just overall it feels like they ran out of time/money to spend on this and threw together what they could as a proof of concept. And it's a good concept, so I'm willing to buy the game and play through it to support them. It's fun enough for atleast a single playthrough IMO.

I'm not very far in yet (that's what she said), but up to this point I'm only able to mine one (1) (a singular) block at a time when digging, and it's legitimately giving me finger cramps. I hope that changes at some point with new mining utilities but if not, Jesus H. Christ on a rubber crutch.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009774013', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 489, 'last_played': 1701294437}
review: Got to this one pretty late but having a lot of fun with it. Really excited about the next game in the series.

author: {'steamid': '76561198147523715', 'num_games_owned': 158, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1157, 'last_played': 1701183046}
review:
Realms of magic is a fun RPG with sandbox parts thrown in. I see it as a mix between Terraria and a better Starbound. The dialogue can be pretty fun, the world is interesting. There is a bunch of combat customizability and the progression in the game can feel pretty rewarding.

The art in the game is pretty on point, the music is pretty good too. 

There might be some quality of life things I'd like to see in this game. But the development team says it is struggling with spaghetti code. It is understandable that they cannot easily make such changes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117154689', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 663, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 663, 'last_played': 1701102257}

author: {'steamid': '76561198053508937', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 345, 'last_played': 1701755186}
review: While the game plays well enough, and the premise is a decent one, I've just a couple sticking points that make me fail to recommend this game. One, the auto save function, it has caused many deaths in game by triggering at stupid times, and with no way to turn it off, nor turn the timer way, way up, it is a massive inconvenience. and two, as small of a matter as it is, I'm tired of games with female character models that seem to suffer from a severe case of androgyny.  Otherwise this game has its act together, it is just those two matters I've mentioned that have kept me from playing this game any further.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011765625', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 27, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1700937931}

author: {'steamid': '76561198056093224', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 610, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 556, 'last_played': 1700800509}
review:
So far after 9 hours, 
Pros, 
Its got everything i wished Terraria had.. EG. High Fantasy! Towns, quests n NPC's, and different area's n zones to travel to and from.

Cons,
a lot missing that Terraria has that it does not have.. EG. Multiplayer, Deeper exploration, dynamic spawns, increased difficulty with depth. Biome creation, and biomes affecting spawns. little things like that, which wouldn't hurt the game/ NOT talking bout a terraria re-skin however.

A Yes vote. Will update my review with more time in-game

author: {'steamid': '76561197990655811', 'num_games_owned': 627, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 2843, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2843, 'last_played': 1696632601}
review:
+++ Good variety of materials for creative work.
+++ Beautifully-detailed and laid-out plot areas.
+++ Serious, grounded story.
+++ Nicely-drawn environments.

--- Imprecise melee combat.
--- Frustrating sidequest requirements.
--- Anonymous free-roam environments.

This interesting beast proposes a blend between story and creation, in which the world is split into both handmade and procedurally-generated areas.  Refreshingly, the plotline neither sugar-coats not satirizes the fantasy-medieval genre, and this makes for interesting dramas that unfold along the way. While the creative aspect of the game is its strong point, it requires slogging through soulless, featureless environments to gather resources. It makes for a budget-oriented title for those who like more plot exposition and less sink-or-swim than Terraria.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011211672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 2992, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2992, 'last_played': 1694295665}
review: Overall its a fun game but I'd hold out for a sale if you're going to get it. Took about 36 hours to complete all the quests and achievements though you could probably do it quicker if you get sidetracked less than I did. Most of the professions are an afterthought... the bulk of my leveling in professions was through scrolls found as loot. I never actually used Husbandry yet still leveled it to 89 without trying by the end of the game. Actual use of crafting was often overshadowed by item drops being better. By the time you've unlocked the area with the raw materials you need, leveled associated skills to turn raw material into bars/rope/cloth/planks/etc., and unlocked the next batch of weapons and equipment to forge... you've probably been overloaded with multiple copies of far better items as drops from enemies while just playing the plotline. Mining and base building was almost unnecessary. And money is abundant. At most I spent it on vegetables and glass vials. I think I had about 3500g by the end of the game, and used about 200g to buy up some profession levels just to finish the achievements. It's by no means a tough game either... I barely had to use up any potions to make it through major fights. If you're looking for a challenge... it's not this game. If you're looking for a fun 20-30 hour game you might play twice, this is worth taking a look at.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991906210', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1209, 'last_played': 1693435812}
review:
Overall, I recommend it (Although, not for the current asking-price ~15€ ).  

I don't agree with the other reviews who compared it to Morrowind. Other than having rpg-elements (Skills improve by using them), it got nothing in common with Morrowind. But I guess this depends on your experience. 
 
I think gameplay wise a comparison to Terraria is still closer, even closer to Starbound if you ask me. 

I haven't finished it yet and I don't think I will, but I still had fun playing it. 

 
My recommendation is if you are interested in it, play it for the first 1,5 hours. The gameplay pretty much does not change after this. The game is not truly open-world, it's tiered. 

All the resources will be simply replaced by higher-tier resources once you unlock the new tier. Copper -> Iron, Pine wood -> Birch wood, Burlap Cloth -> Wool Cloth, Copper-weapons -> Iron-weapons and so on. I haven't found any exotic or interesting equipment, it’s always close to stuff you already have, just with a different stat-distribution.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008208124', 'num_games_owned': 437, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 3003, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 825, 'last_played': 1698195641}
review:
This is a Terraria RPG (with Elder Scrolls vibes). Early game (first 20 hours) is sweet. Mid game is okay, and late game (After 35+ hours) is getting very boring. The resources get rarer and more difficult to obtain, and you are required to do even more grinding to upgrade your skills. 

At first I thought that Negative reviews here are simple complaints. But then I start to see how valid they are after 40 hours.

Pros:
-Nice level designs of Locations, each unique and interesting. 
-Nice Character Progression, from rag-clothes to a warrior in shining plates, gradual and satisfying upgrade. 
-Base Building
-Farming, Mining, Crafting
-Some quests are nice, funny. 
-Reactions of NPCs are well worked in early game (I find NPCs of late game towns are more bland). 

Cons:
-Simple fighting which using active skills is difficult and not satisfying. 
-Grind, grind, grind. It could be acceptable, if I am not required to wait very long time in front of screen waiting for some crafting jobs done. Each crafting takes at least 1-2 seconds as average and you are required to do 100-200 of them when you are trying to unlock next skill levels to unlock better items. Then the game starts to become boring.
-Many quests are obtaining item or collecting enough resources, which is boring.
-Finding gear/weapon items are almost never satisfying, when you find them, they are almost always in worse quality than your equipment. 
-Same underground maps for mining. 
-Enemies are just skinned versions of each other. Enemy types are few: Melee chaser, Ranged/Spellcaster, Brute (Cyclops, Minotaurs), that's it. 

My early review was Positive, it became Negative after 40+ hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985836415', 'num_games_owned': 724, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 622, 'last_played': 1693440621}

author: {'steamid': '76561198026535029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 346, 'last_played': 1693274902}
review: Grab it on sale. It's currently $3 and worth every cent. Like somebody else said, it is like the Elder Scrolls in a Terraria world. Everything you do - mining, crafting - increases your respective skill. You are questing while growing your skills necessary for the story progression. There are quest locations on the map, but it is an open world in the sense that you can go to any non-quest location to collect resources and find randomly placed secrets (typically, chests underground). It is easy fun. Even if there was no story, it is easily enjoyable because of the open world exploration element. I highly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119540748', 'num_games_owned': 163, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 263, 'last_played': 1690238199}
review:
I got this game for 3 bucks on sale. 
Apparently they will be giving away a remastered version for people who own it for free at a later date, with new systems. mechanics, and UI, so that alone is a steal. 

I have never really played Terraria or anything like it. I understand there is a few complainers of the games mechanics when comparing it to that game, however, I find it to be a much needed relaxed, low stakes game that I was looking for. While this game is visually like Terraria, as others said before me, it is much more akin to an Elder Scrolls game. To me it seems almost like Daggerfall without having to mod it to relentlessly to enjoy it. Do what you want, how you want. There's even choices within the quests they give you. Plus you can homestead, and mix and match all the skill trees and make whatever class you want. 
if you like RPGs with a side of survival mechanics (if you want to pursue that) then get this on a discount and you're in for a treat!

author: {'steamid': '76561199478351290', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 945, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 320, 'last_played': 1704579402}

author: {'steamid': '76561198043857299', 'num_games_owned': 1159, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 2588, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2588, 'last_played': 1689771207}
review:
This game has a lot of good ideas going on: great pixel graphics, many items to collect, the instanced cells with the sandbox ones for item farming and the fixed ones for quests and secrets, an entertaining skills system, even if a little grindy, the possibility of crafting with ingredients in near containers.

It's far from perfect though.
The combat is uninspired: I abandoned melee early on to become an ice mage (then the combat became trivial). There are many items, but they are only stat boosts, there are no unique effects among them.

I had a fun time with it, and I'm looking foward to see what the devs will do with the sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970571834', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 1314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 192, 'last_played': 1690395475}
review:
yes milord

EDIT: After playing more I agree with the other reviewer who stated this feels like Morrowind in it's general vibe and especially the great orchestral sound track. Love the crafting and massive variety of crafting options. Alchemy is fundamental and potions give a massive boost to mining, crafting, and woodcutting. If you are struggling with mining (someone was complaining in another review about mining being too slow) bear that in mind. Also try to fully explore a biome/area before you travel to the next one you have unlocked. Each biome/area is an 'Act' in the game and every time you unlock a new one the difficulty scales and increases gradually, including the difficulty of mining rocks so prepare accordingly before moving onto the next area.

This isn't the kind of game where you funnel everything into one skill and expect to succeed. To progress your character invest in all your skills in order to level up and search for every last secret (don't forget to keep your torch equipped) for extra talent points. There are some odd typos and missed punctuation but there is a lot of brilliant descriptive and funny writing in this game so I don't agree with the person who was complaining about the English translation.

Yes there are some janky bits and oddities but learning to master attack swing patterns and positioning makes a big difference. For example when swinging a sword the 3rd swing is a stab that you should move back in your positioning to maximise its damage. I feel these elements of the game are intentional and skill based.

I held out on this game for the better part of a year but SO glad I finally picked it up on sale and am having a blast. If this looks like your kind of game but you are not sure, I would definitely recommend picking it up.

Yes it is clear to see inspiration taken from Terraria and Starbound but this game feels much more intimate and 'close-up' than those. It is slower paced and you can really take your time to enjoy building, crafting and exploring the world. Surprisingly, crafting systems feel a lot more like World of Warcraft's professions than those in Runescape. Which to me is great.

In terms of gameplay loop I find myself doing the following things:
Take every quest from the main town of a biome/area. Explore every nook and cranny of non-quest unique locations for secrets, and items. Scour a couple of randomly generated sandbox tiles. Then return to base armed with items and goodies to do some crafting and tick off quest objectives. Afterward I return to the town and complete quests and pick up any followup quests. Then I might settle down on my farming tile which is next to my homestead to pick and plant crops.

I give this game a solid 8 or 9 out of 10 for its ability to captivate and engage me.

Some wishes for the future:
Range weapons - bows/xbows/darts/throwing knives etc.
A combat Arena - face an ever increasing wave of deadly monsters and/or arena contenders for glory, cash or reward points
Water - Include water and the ability to swim in 4 dimensions, up down left right. Maybe add ocean or beach tiles where we can explore the seas and dive down into temples and wrecks.
Shapeshifting spells- Being able to become a shapeshifting druid who can transform into a bear or other wild creature
Increased villager options- hire peasants and other workers for your town/homestead and be able to tax them and set living conditions and have a community vault that when you pay into it, funds for living standards and other things are taken from it. (This is a big wish)
Increased diversity of randomly generated tiles and create more objects of interest in both the overworld and underground.

I could probably go on with improvements and wishes for the game and hope the developers continue with their current level of passion and love for their game. This is a real gem. Thank you for coming to my TED talk.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058592137', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 4820, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2962, 'last_played': 1690154791}

author: {'steamid': '76561198011764487', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1701, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1701, 'last_played': 1688787240}
review:
Pros: The game has some nice elements and decent mechanics. 
Cons: The game is extremely poorly optimised, there are frequent lag spikes making platforming and combat frustrating. There are a lot of bugs, and the devs seem to ignore them. I looked at the game discussions to see if I was the only one, and the bugs I experienced have been reported but are still not fixed years later.

It's a shame because the game showed promise, but this is at best a beta, sold as a release.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019197650', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1261, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1261, 'last_played': 1688440155}
review:
The option t mine and craft is something in many games, this one is par for this, 

The issue I have with the game would be. 

1 Battle mechanics, not very rewarding in terms of play, 

2 Map layouts, both session and overall maps,   Session maps, generally will have where you are on a quest at a location, and you must get to some part of the map, in an open area you can build and change it how you need too, for quest areas this feature is limited to only, Special areas that you can dig, combine this with places you need to jump a special way, its is really a tired concept that takes away from the crafting , leveling up of your Character.

3. Overall map is locked till you complete quests and do tasks,  so if you want to play open world you will be stuck in tech since there are no animials, or plants in the first area that give you options , you can buy them but won't be able to find them in the wild.  Plus enemies you face will be at first area levels as well.  

Some bugs that have existed since early on and have been talked about are still in the game, this leads me to believe the developers simple do not play the game they make,  

Magic in the game is very much a let down, and people you recruit to your settlement are simply vendors,  

Skip this game , play Craft the World ,

author: {'steamid': '76561197997257316', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 955, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 346, 'last_played': 1703537801}
review: This game is almost fun.  It's got a lot of systems that could be great, but everything feels half-done.  The crafting is ok, I guess, but nothing amazing.  It's pretty linear - craft each thing once to get the "first craft" bonus to get enough to unlock the next thing which unlocks the next, and so on.  Combat is atrocious.  Enemy hitboxes are bonkers.  My sword more often than not completely overlaps the enemy sprite without a hit being detected.  It feels like the hitboxes are off to the side of the enemy, particularly when they are doing any kind of attack.  There's also zero impact or collision, so combat with more than two combatants is just everything in the same space flailing wildly.  Mining is adequate, but painfully slow until you've upgraded your pickaxe, which requires a lot of mining.  The "zones" are clones of each other with the same landscape and resources just one tier higher - tin becomes copper, jute becomes linen, etc.  It's basically palette-shifting the entire world, so after you've completed the first zone you've seen everything.  The quests are really disappointing - they frequently hint at more complex stories, but very rarely are you given any way to interact with those.  There's a guy who beats his wife in the first town.  People will tell you about it, his wife is obviously afraid when you talk to her, and there's a quest that intersects with that.  However, you cannot interact with that piece of information at all.  For how much the game tells you about it, it really feels like you are meant to be able to.  Instead, it's all just fetch-quests.  Again, half-done.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076461596', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 715, 'last_played': 1703472887}
review: Really enjoy this game, hope they keep updating it and DLC's

author: {'steamid': '76561198086229928', 'num_games_owned': 848, 'num_reviews': 172, 'playtime_forever': 2446, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2446, 'last_played': 1688067516}
review:
Despite what it looks like, this is absolutely nothing like Terraria. Its a lot closer to something like Morrowind, but you can actually hit shit in this game, and the writing is only good enough, and not excellent, like Morrowind's.

The platforms are kinda wonky and standing on their edges wont count, and sometimes the game turns on the sneak mode and you move abysmally slowly. For a couple hours i didnt know that it turned it on by itself and i was frustrated by this. Look in the controls and turn it back on, it happens sometimes. Platforming can be wonky in this game because your character stops sprinting when your cursor is behind them, and running out of stamina mid jump will slow you down, and thats stupid, since its not you moving yourself at that point, but momentum itself.

Honestly, out of all the ARPG's i've played i enjoyed this the most. Torchlight II and Grim Dawn just didnt grab me, probably because the isometric perspective feels so disconnected from the action, unlike this game. I wish this game had New Game +

To get the profession achievements fast, grind Major potions from the enemies in the final area or craft them, they sell for a stupid amount of gold, then have trainers train you. If you're missing the blackwall sidequests, go back to the crossroads inn. The NPC's come back and they have quests

TL;DR: Fun ARPG, the only overlap between this and Terraria are the fun building mechanics, nothing else. Kinda wonky, No new game +, still fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971889651', 'num_games_owned': 1050, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2268, 'last_played': 1686176872}

author: {'steamid': '76561199263812328', 'num_games_owned': 79, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 1255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 456, 'last_played': 1690474676}
review:
this is the first game i've played that made ALCHEMY actually god-tier...it's so helpful for a small investment

there are many things i'd like to talk about the game but the number 1 thing in the game in my opinion is how good ALCHEMY is compared to many games...which i will compare to Fallout 4's drugs ( temporary buffs )

the ALCHEMY cost little and is quite effective...it's cheap, no ultra rare item you have to test your luck to find even once in your playthrough and the effect is both strong and durable......STRONG EFFECT AND DURABLE......not just some 10-20% buff over something for 30 seconds...i'm talking about 50% buffs for 15 minutes......all you need is a vial with water, a common plant or 2, a common monster drop that can be bought for cheap...and presto! you can deforest an area 50% faster or speed up mining by 50% for 15 minutes aswell!.....how could anyone skip on that????....even the basic potions are worth using...healing 30%+ of your hp over a few seconds, refill your mana at a decent rate to spam the hell out of your magic and refill your stamina for unlimited sprint ( can be paired with the speed potion for speedrunning enthusiast )


if we compare the  "temporary buffs"  with Fallout 4...Fallout's drugs gives tiny to small bonuses to your attributes or give a tactical advantage and only last 10-60 sec...and they are not common to find...and they're not cheap........wtf.....would you rather get a 50% bonus to your mining or wood chopping for 15 minutes with a tiny cost of common items easy to acquire or spend an hour scavenging for drugs or "waiting" 48 hours to restock vendors just so you can have a small benefit over something for 10-60 sec?





HEY DEV(S) JUST FOR THAT ALONE...JUST FOR MAKING AN OFTEN TERRIBLE ASPECT OF A GAME ACTUALLY USEFUL FOR ANYONE...YOU GOT MY PRAISE!







since i've stated out the best thing in the game ( compared to many other games' way for alchemy )...let's talk about the bad sides


the buy and sell prices when you start are atrociously bad...but thank god leveling up the trading skill makes prices go in your favor for income and price tags

the enemies are kinda basic and stupid...it is mostly fine how it is for the genre....but enemies should hide when they're getting shot at by magic spells ( ice bolt and fire ball for example )...they might just stand above you or under you unable to hit you and just stand there like idiots taking shots in the face....at least the humanoids enemies should be smart enough to hide from projectiles if they're unable to hit back ( possible hit detection according to the player's location and where they can move )

there are some common bugs that fix themselves shortly after they happend ( unable to place block, attibute point not detected, etc. )...not game breaking but they may happend once per hour

the human race is pretty much the best race in my opinion...having bonuses in pretty much everything...that's why i picked a high elf, to not have too much hp and stamina so i feel more the need to invest in magic stuffs

and spekaing of races...most races are not really worth picking since they lack advantages over the human race...i picked a 10% dmg bonus and double magic resistance over higher health and much higher stamina as starting stats ( starting with 40 stamina sucks, trust me )

THE BIGGEST FLAW tho is the lack of option to Romance the village idiot in the starting village...at least give us the option to give him a little smooch on the cheek...after wiping out the dirt off it...or not, if you're a weirdo




other than that...the game is FANTASTIC!    8.5 outta 10

author: {'steamid': '76561199191521681', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 3049, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2858, 'last_played': 1685833135}

author: {'steamid': '76561197994661904', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1115, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1083, 'last_played': 1686607130}
review:
I like almost every single thing about the game. It tries and succeeds at so much for a 2d side scroll-er.   Charismatic and highly detailed graphics that's a mix of pixel, hand drawn and fx.  Superb sound effects and soundtrack.  intuitive and functional user interface.  Another game like The elder scrolls that allows you to pick up and read books, notes and letters to explore the lore of the world.  you can even construct your own library to store the books in. 
  Sadly the game isn't perfect.  The AI of the enemies is really wonky at this stage.  maybe they can upgrade it in a future patch.  A jarring technical dilemma is that you can't control the cameras zoom except with a setting in the games graphics.  witch is fine because there are already so many key binds.  But whats weird is the zoom you can choose varies depending on your screen resolution.  If you are playing on a low res screen your maximum zoom is limited.  But if you have a 4k screen you can see a very large area of the map.
  As of this I have only played 15 hours or so.  Since its an rpg with a big undertaking I expect to the game to be a mind numbing blissfully fun time sink.

author: {'steamid': '76561198986844862', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1341, 'last_played': 1685400835}
review: this review may be edited in the future, but in its current state, this is one of those games where you play until you get bored, then put it on the shelf for six months to a year. You come back to see whats new/changed. Be cautious, content fixes/updates are sparse.

author: {'steamid': '76561199406103927', 'num_games_owned': 36, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 663, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 314, 'last_played': 1683409572}
review:
Introduction:

Being 20 dollars, this is a MUST buy, and if ever on sale a HAVE TO buy, i bought this game seeing it was much like terraria, and i certainly enjoy terraria it seems to be pretty cookie cutter start to finish. however, realms, on the other hand has many great qualities that exceed expectations, and personally terraria. Cons were very hard to come up with and i was really happy about a lot of the features and mechanics in game. 

Note: i am a melee build and havent used anything else such as magic, so i have no insight on the topic so far.

Pros:
-you can farm all sorts of things just like minecraft.
-lot of races to pick with unique background lore and bonuses and deficits that are specific to the race.
-love the graphics, looks like a classic game of the style would look like.
-the feel of the game is pretty smooth, and while not perfect, i have no complaints about navigation, movement, or combat.
-i can see the list of craftables in the crafting station menu and theres at least a dozen tiers of gears for weapons, armor, and tools, quite extensive.
-with only 5 hours on the books i can see this easily being in the double to triple digits for anyone whose a fan of the style.
-very RPG oriented. as terraria is the only similar game i can compare to this game definitely has lore, from races in character creation, to story, to books and notes found in game. 
-classic fantasy sword and sorcery. not to my knowledge or what ive played so far is there an guns or unicorn wands or things of the nature, very classic style weapons, which i enjoy over, over-the-top weapons and items.
-you switch between like a creation mode, where you can destroy/place blocks, mine, place chests/crafting stations and a combat mode where you have access to a primary weapon, shield and skills/abilities. this double bar system just allows for more compared to terraria/minecraft.
-crafting is very nice, with about 6-8 different crafting stations that you can work with, food, tailor, smelting, smithing, alchemy, etc. all having their own experience gain and levels to work towards.
-between the tutorial and the starting missions game gives a very nice grasp at how to get started
-quite a few skill trees that unlock some nice things.

Cons: 
-only able to hit one mob at a time so far, which makes group fights kind of clunky, but with dodging and jumping certainly can help.
-skill tree diversity, you will more than likely need 2-3 trees to progress at a time to avoid constant surplus of points, as you will gain talent points from scrolls as well as levels so they can add up and if you only intend on using 1-2 trees, your going to be sitting on a handful of points until next milestone (every 5 levels).
-Unique equipment doesnt really have anything special about them, just seemingly more damage, which makes the unique name weapons somewhat lackluster
- combat can be stale as weapons of a type only really have 1 combo your constantly using, however more variety in the single combo than terraria/minecraft.
-one area for sure i couldnt get back up. it was in a map i couldnt alter so i had to travel out and back to get from where i was. not a huge deal, just minor inconvenience.
-only including this for those that prefer a very open ended and free roam experience, that areas are dependent on quests. (Areas have dozens of sandbox areas and about half a dozen named areas) 
-sometimes dialogue isnt perfect for grammar.
-although i have not, and i am sure you can, autosave can hit at very poor times, like in the middle of combat or trying to do something.

Conclusion:

At the end of the day, if you like old school side scrollers, games like terraria and minecraft with a nice sandbox style, but crave a more RPG experience, this is definitely for you. i am a big fan of both of those listed games and while fun, can get boring as there isnt anything to really pay attention to other than your own self made goals i.e. base building, gear, bosses, etc. the cons list is all trivial stuff and minor inconveniences at best as with 5 hours under my belt i really dont see anything wrong with the game, zero bugs so far, no glitches, no crashes, and runs fine. very well put together, well executed, definitely real time and effort has been put into this game and it really shows, unlike a lot of games that dont really deliver nowadays, this one certainly does. i enjoy clearing every zone, and getting my crafting skills to max, so i can easily see myself in the triple digits EASY on this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107014278', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 214, 'playtime_forever': 1477, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1682785822}
review:
Esta bueno, falla en cosas basicas del genero pero es interesante... por ahora solo me limite a terminar la historia

empiezo por lo malo:
-el combate: bastante pobre y en el nivel mas facil es ridiculo, no te presenta ningun reto... las espadas no se diferencian en nada mas que el daño que hacen, todas se mueven igual y no aporta nada interesante al combate... el swing de el arma cuerpo a cuerpo solo afecta al primer enemigo que se cruza, es decir, si hay un grupo de enemigos el sablazo de tu espada solo afecta al primero que toca, y no a todos los enemigos, se hace muy tedioso si queres matar grupos de mobs
-el autosaving no se puede desactivar, podes ponerlo con una diferencia de mucho tiempo pero es muy molesto estar jugando y que de la nada se congele el juego porque esta autoguardando la partida
-la papelera es una porqueria: la papelera es basicamente lo mismo que tirar los objetos al lado tuyo, no cumple ninguna funcion... no se deshace de los items, los deja a un lado y si al tiempo pasaste por al lado el item sigue estando ahi... encima hay items que no se pueden ni vender, si no los queres no podes reciclarlos, no te queda otra que dejarlos en alguna parte del mapa a la que no te interese ir mas o dejarlo en un cofre propio abandonado
-el orden automatico del inventario te ordena todo sin tener en cuenta las mochilas, si queres ordenar automaticamente una mochila en especifica no se puede, te ordena todo el inventario repartiendolo en todas las mochilas, si tenias items ordenados por comida (por ej) te los va a poner en cualquier mochila dependiendo de que otros items haya antes
-el sprint: mal hecho, para esprintar el cursor del mouse tiene que estar mirando a la direccion a la que se esta esprintando, es muy facil ir esprintando y sin querer mover el cursor hacia el otro costado, automaticamente se deja de esprintar
-no se puede deshacer una mision: si aceptaste una mision secundaria y queres abandonarla, mucha suerte! vas a tenerla en el journal por el resto del juego, no se puede abandonar ninguna mision

lo bueno:
-la historia esta buena, te atrapa y los guiones son excelentes, muy ocurrentes
-variedad de armaduras, clases y armas
-el mapa es enorme, te da pie a investigar y se nota que hay bastante por investigar
-la musica es llevadera, acorde al clima de la historia

se que puse muchas cosas malas pero eso no quiere decir que disfrute el juego, solo que estaria bueno que cosas tan basicas como las que nombre no existan

author: {'steamid': '76561197993374759', 'num_games_owned': 470, 'num_reviews': 177, 'playtime_forever': 864, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1703128106}
review:
So far, it's "slow Terraria with more RPG stuff and some story, but way less fun combat and painfully slow mining"... and that's about it.
The game needs more combat polish, less per-weapon skills on the skill trees and maybe a few more weapon types, or another more generic skill tree mixed in, as most of the skills are so locked in on a specific concept that you have almost no reason to branch out or experiment.
(Basically, you've got the light weapon tree, the heavy weapon tree, the defense tree, and four magic trees. If you use maces, you use one narrow branch on the heavy weapon tree, plus the defense tree, and that's it.)

It's still pretty underbaked for being a "full release" version of the game, but I still like it and would still recommend it to people looking for "slow Terraria but RPG", if you're looking for something like that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026663817', 'num_games_owned': 986, 'num_reviews': 354, 'playtime_forever': 277, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 277, 'last_played': 1679082210}
review:
It manages to avert some issues that Terraria and Starbound have... but everything just feels incredibly half-hearted. The combat in particular - there's no impact. And no real threat, either. I actually think the game would've been [i]better[/i] if they got rid of the combat altogether.

There's a nice mixture of unchangeable, hand-crafted areas (villages, dungeons) and unlocked sandbox areas where you can just build whatever you want, plant crops, place crafting stations etc. I found building to be rather grindy, though - I needed a lot of materials to get what I wanted, and getting them was not the fun kind of grind. Many different options as to what to build and which materials to use; and they only expand as you increase your trade skills.

The locked areas actually felt like videogame levels with secrets, and that's great. I'd say it's the best part of the game: exploration of even a small pit with rats felt fun. Or rather it would've been fun if the combat had any weight to it.

Everything else - the dialogue, the quests, the world... there's clearly some effort here. But, how to say this... it felt like reading a badly written novel? You can tell that someone put their heart and soul into this but the result is just boring, and it... hurts, you know?

The game lacks this magic. This vision. Nothing seems to fit together. And it doesn't look like the game has any real design philosophy, so it probably never will.

[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/42922988/]Curator Page[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561197966358311', 'num_games_owned': 912, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 402, 'last_played': 1679884671}
review:
Cute little game. Like a more traditional RPG version of terraria.

BUT. and its a big one.

The combat. Is. Atrociously bad. Like worse than any 8 or 16 bit game ever made. And it's made worse by the skills in the game. There are literally skills that are "100% extra damage with weapon type X". Which makes ZERO sense as you basically have to pick a SINGLE weapon type and just roll with it for the whole game. So 90% of weapons you pick up are useless. They also take too much stamina if you don't have the tree specced. It's just horribly thought out from A to Z.

And the actual animations on the weapons are fucking painful. No way to attack up or down or at any angle. Enemy attacks ALL see to me charge at you in melee and many of them instantly turn around when they pass through you and hit you in the back. It's honestly just an exercise in frustration.

HARD PASS on the combat alone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198836692007', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 528, 'last_played': 1677939698}
review:
What is it:
Something like terraria, but much less freedom, much less variety and much more story and more rpg. You do quests, grind, craft, you can build too (well, you would need resources, which are boring pain to grind, so for me - no desire to build at all), although you can not terraform cities, but only free areas on map

Cons:
1) Grind, grind, grind. Boring, endless, senseless grind. Well, you would grind in terratia too, but here it is much more senseless, grindy and boring.
2) Unballanced skills - summons on higher difficulty are completely useless compared to melee, didn't want to try anything else
3) Very limited enemy variety that gets repetitive very quickly
4) Clunky combat overall
5) When you enter a village - you do it always from the left side of the map. If you want to visit someone on the right edge of the city map - you go there all the way every time, which is not short, and you do it often due to the game is heavy on quests.

Pros:
1) Crafting system is nice but doesn't fall too smoothly over the core of gameplay
2) Some amount of not-so-bad humor

author: {'steamid': '76561198306965757', 'num_games_owned': 230, 'num_reviews': 192, 'playtime_forever': 2640, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 212, 'last_played': 1686801178}
review:
I'm not sure how much I'll like the leveling system blocking crafting recipes, but I'd say this is a pretty worth while game even if you have to craft a bunch of items you'll never use just to get the skill's exp.

Edit: Yeah... I'm kinda getting sick and tired of the leveling system. The grind is tedious for certain skills but quick and easy for others so the scaling or level of tedium for gaining exp for certain skills is really really, and I mean a giant pain.
Like I went from level 1 husbandry to level 48 in half an hour. But my crafting skill is still too low to complete certain quests which I find strange given how much more considerable time I have spent crafting things to build a giant base with. And that's a second thing. The grind. 
You have to spend so much time in the sandbox element to gather resources and loot chests and fight enemies to level up all of the necessary skills to advance. And that's ignoring the main leveling system regarding your character's level. This exp bar is the slowest of them all. I'm only level 15 and it's been almost a day of playing this game. How realistically am I expected to reach level 25 let alone anything past that with how petty the rewards for quests are? That's also ignoring there's no basic ranged weapons. 
You have to level up abilities to get anything canon fodder or range related. No bow? Spent ages trying to figure out how to craft one. Can't. I can't get anywhere in the third zone because of how slow the pvp is. Dodging and weaving in this game is really boring. Like REALLY boring. I spent all my skill points from player leveling up on using less stamina on running and dodge rolling. I have nothing in actual abilities because if I didn't have them fights would go on longer as I would have to run away and hide to get my stamina back. 

The difficulty curve doesn't make all that much sense. It seems like certain enemies are just op for no reason other than that they can. While it seems like anything around that enemy is just swiss cheese. This game plays very similar to Starbound because I used an RPG mod to have specialized classes and a leveling system. But at least with that, anything you did contributed to your player level instead of just the specific skill stat. Maybe this game does that too and it was too little to actually do much. The only exp I really seem to get are from fights, looting chests, or quests. The quests are kind of dogsh*t too. Not because they're boring or anything. It's that they have prerequisites. Especially the ones in the third zone because the game expects you to be a certain level in your skills to complete quests which frankly doesn't make much sense. 
You can't craft items being asked of you, and either have to buy them from merchants selling them from previous zones, or grind leveling for it. There's no good way of grinding your grinding skill to unlock flour recipe or unlock corn. You can't get corn in this zone or any previous zone so it mystifies me that there would be a quest that required it. You can buy the cornmeal which is what you need, but still. 
The money grind isn't as tedious as other games because you just gradually accumulate wealth and can sell junk for quick cash. But I find myself spending quite a bit of it on basic items because of them being tedious to craft or harvest, and wanting to craft the raw resources into items I'll actually use. I mean I get that's the appeal of MMO's or whatever but like this game is designed to have multiple playthroughs. How the hell is that ever going to happen if I'm stuck on one character that can't get past level 15? 


Edit 2: I'll thank you to not convolute basic game mechanics or better yet not account for reactions people will have to certain dialogue results. Why would you have like "Oh the humanity." or "I'm just a small little goblin please do not kill me!" when not killing certain individuals will actually prevent you from completing the game or getting rewards like exp or gold? Like you can't even go back on certain actions. 

Game has no wiki so there's no way of knowing before hand. So the fact you peacefully resolved the issues between the elves and the humans of whatever the name of the second area is means you've essentially made it mandatory to play the game from start to finish a second time to actually complete the game, 100% which the game really wants you to do. 

So why it would f*ck you over and make that impossible is beyond me. Like you can't kill what are certainly individuals you will be tasked to kill later on, ahead of time, and instead have to figure out who you need to talk to, so you can do the thing you already knew you were eventually going to do.

I can't stand it. 

You can have items needed to complete quests ahead of time but the fucking tedium of stalling the inevitable is such a pain in the ass. I don't know why you'd have things that are straight forward and just convoluted something that should be just as simple. It's not fun. It's annoying. Keep it simple. Not like this game will get that update anytime soon.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977427832', 'num_games_owned': 469, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 265, 'last_played': 1679260170}
review:
Combat is stale and slow, character movement is rigid and clunky, and crafting is over-complex for a game like this.  They were doing so many things with this game, but it would've all been a lot better if combat alone were better polished.  They could've done better taking some direction from games like Salt & Sanctuary.
* Enemies clump up, but you can only hit one at a time.
* Only melee weapons available unless you learn magic.
* Very... very... very slow and sluggish swinging motions.
* Stamina cost on basic attacks doesn't fit the "large group of enemies coming at you" thematic when you can only stab one at a time anyway.
* Attacks don't feel like they have any power or impact to them.

The main thing the game did right, however, was the locations system with the map... I love that part.
I'd say the professions system is okay, but incredibly slow.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003951567', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1847, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1847, 'last_played': 1678161132}
review:
I have completed the game and now have 100% of the achievements.  However, I personally would not recommend this game.  It has some good qualities but there are many aspects of the game that I did not find enjoyable.  My biggest issue is that the character and gear progression did not feel very good.  The only difference between tiers of weapons is simply the damage.  This made weapon progression not very exciting, basically, I would get to a new zone, enemies would have more hp, and as a result I'd need a new weapon with more damage to compensate.  Since the only difference is more damage and enemies now had more health essentially nothing had changed.  Also I feel like there was a huge missed opportunity with the uniquely named weapons in this game.  You can find these weapons with unique names in the world, however they behave exactly like every other weapon, I think giving these unique effects or extra stats would have greatly improved the variety of weapons.

Character progression in regards to talents also felt sort of lackluster.  While the talents were usually impactful, many of the times my levels ups offered nothing of use.  This is due to the fact that talents in a tree are typically 5 levels apart.  This led to me unlocking a new talent in my mace weapon tree, putting a point there, and then waiting another 5 levels to unlock the next talent.  There were a few talents in the combat tree that were nice, and the frost barrier was great, but I saw no appeal in putting points into other trees as they did not support my build.  This led to me having an excess of talent points with nothing interesting to use them on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038037146', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 1812, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1274, 'last_played': 1677864316}
review:
I had low expectations. The art is ... um. Low-budget indie. It is of course basically Terraria / Minecraft under the hood. And on a keyboard + mouse, it can be a little tricky since side-scroller platformers for me are just kind of anchored to a hand-held controller.

And then I kept playing. And every time I went into one of the pre-built maps to explore or do a quest or something, I kept encountering some interesting little platformer obstacle course to navigate or discovered a secret hidden chest or was surprised by an uber mob I'd never seen before. And although the English localization is absolutely swamped with spelling errors and awkward phrasing, I found the dialogues and plot to be, well, charmingly sincere and executed with the distinct style of a well-worn song that is performed perfectly, without wonky gimmicks or kitschy in-jokes. Movement and combat are precise and responsive which is pretty important for this type of game. Base building and supply management is satisfying without being horribly grindy (though, let's be real, a *leeeettle bit* of grind is why we play this genre anyway). And although the sprites are... primitive... the variety of fashion options for personal customization is larger than I expected.

My main complaint is that the variety of active skills available is extremely small. You'll be using the same spell or type of weapon for basically 90% of the game from the tutorial on. And almost all of the talents just give you minor passive scaling to keep up with the hit points of enemy creatures as you go. Which is painfully boring and a waste of the game's potential as a platform adventurer. There are also some pretty glaring balance problems which can saddle you with a burning resentment after you realize that you can't respec your character for a long time yet but getting more points is going to take forever and all the points you've spent so far don't really matter because your summoned rats and wolves do pathetic damage and die instantly, even after wasting all your gear to pump them. Meanwhile even the weak ice bolt is doing twenty times the damage with one shot and you haven't even got any gear equipped for it and hardly any points spent in that tree. And your ice bolt goes where you tell it to instead of sitting around next to enemies, unresponsive.

The developer is (slowly) continuing to work on it. It's got all the potential of Terraria but has a far more narrative / RPG architecture with some absolutely fantastic level design. Hopefully they address the combat powers / talents to make them more interesting and varied soon.

I have to admit it's worth the pricetag even if they don't, though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042308284', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 1395, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1394, 'last_played': 1675258235}
review:
Искал 2D песочницу, чтоб испытать то чувство, которое я испытывал, когда впервые запустил Майнкрафт и Террарию, чувство, которое говорит, что ты похеришь в этой игре очень и очень много времени. В итоге после того, как я её запустил прошло 24 часа, и я этого на заметил.
Это тёмное фэнтези, где ломаются судьбы людей, где тебя ставят перед сложным выбором, где тебя обманывают куртизанки, и где деревенский дурачок в награду за украденное платье местной красавицы срёт тебе в инвентарь, в прямом смысле. 
Я был обычным человеком в мире, где происходит какое-то серьёзное дерьмо, но в итоге стал воином, который метает топоры и бегает, как угорелый оставляя за собой огненный след, который поджигает врагов, которые распространяют этот огонь на других злых челов. Я бегал, фармил мобов и делал квесты, забыв, что играю в песочницу, т.к это просто другой путь развития. Здесь ты сам выбираешь, как развиваться. Можно заниматься песочными делами, фармить руду, крафтить, строить дом и населять его продавцами, либо быть наёмником, который просто выполняет задания, получает награды и по пути обучается ремеслу читая свитки и тратя деньги на обучение, а дома можно получить со всеми плюхами за квесты. 

Короче, чукча не писатель, писал тапком, занавес. Из минусов только то, что гоблины и гномы ростом с человека, т.е 3 блока, так что не получится схитрожопить, чтоб копать туннель в два блока. ВОООООТ.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004921664', 'num_games_owned': 150, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 578, 'last_played': 1673987032}
review: I so wanted to like this game. It had everything going for it, but after a few hours play I just had to accept that it is the most ridiculously unbalanced game I've ever played, and that is just unforgivable. There's almost two trees dedicated to summoning, so I decided it would be fun to try being a nature summoner. After a few levels it's completely useless. Want to kill a mighty enemy at level 10 as a summoner on normal mode? It'll take you about 45 minutes (unless the enemy has some life regen, then it's literally impossible). Want to kill the same enemy with basic weapon skills? It'll take you 20 seconds.. How can you offer different play styles and then make some completely unplayable. I've heard it's the same for other magic skills too. I don't expect a 100% perfectly balanced game, but it feels like zero effort went in whatsoever here. Does the developer just not care at all?

author: {'steamid': '76561199006864826', 'num_games_owned': 157, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 4590, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 950, 'last_played': 1677984569}
review:
TLDR; The game is well-built and fun, don't believe the store videos they inaccurately make the game look poorly made
Honestly, the game looks rough when you see it in the store. It seems like it has great ideas but they don't look well implemented. The characters look slightly janky throughout the videos you are shown. But the gameplay is so much different! I fell in love with the game almost immediately. The combat is just hard enough to be fun but not hard enough to be rage-inducing. Crafting feels rewarding. It reminds me a bit of Runescape but gathering materials is much different. Honestly, I couldn't find anything to complain about in this game except for the lack of multiplayer (supposedly it is supposed to come sometime in the future just the devs are focused on the game).

author: {'steamid': '76561198011594532', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 491, 'last_played': 1673677534}
review:
20 hours in, more thoughts.

What I really like:
It's a good use of 2D Terraria environments with a map mechanic to expand playable area. Skills are varied like a true RPG - milling, leatherworking, cooking, etc - and when you level each up through use, it has that Skyrim-esque satisfying drum fill. Graphics strike a nice balance between simple enough to animate on a grid and detailed enough to be pretty. I like how it's clearly both an RPG and a Open World Craft. The mechanics are smooth as butter. It's very clever - like your character has a slot for water and food, so you're not bothering to feed them every 5 minutes. And inventory is copious and bountiful - you have up to 5 additional bags, so there's no lack of space. It's so annoying when you play a craft open world game with thousands of types of things, and a backpack with 24 slots - this game does not have that issue at all.

Oh, and the music is solid. Props to the folks that pulled that together, it's quite good.

What could use some love:
In the third or fourth town, dialogue starts breaking down a little. It feels a little low effort there, some characters are just saying "I hate this place." It's a stretch from the first wizard you encounter that expounds on basics of gameplay. Some of the character visual face combos just look cartoonish, even for a game that isn't aiming for full realism. You can allow villagers to follow you to your camp, but they lack any personality - they're more like objects you collect and place in your camp. Once placed, they stand still like mannequins awaiting replacement. The game has a good variety of objects, but they seem to lack any animation, and as a result feel less alive. Sure you can create and place an outhouse, but it's effectively a static painting.

Overall it has a lot of promise, and I'll likely continue to play it through max level, but I'm not sure if I'll return much after that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075280270', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 6703, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2098, 'last_played': 1704942294}
review:
This game is a jank filled, mindless slog through grinding up various professions, and exploring very similar areas of a map over and over and over and honestly, I absolutely love it.

The animations are nutty, the enemy ai extremely exploitable, the UI is a little wonky, but I can't stop playing. The game has a lot of charm. From the quests from fun NPCs to the respectable amount of world building put into the various races and books scattered across the land, I just kept finding things that had me wondering what was around the next corner. 

This game is absolutely not for everyone. If you're looking for a serious challenge or something to shake up the genre and make it feel new, you're likely not going to find it here. But if you're looking for something to mindlessly play to veg out and occasionally get a good chuckle out of, I'd definitely recommend it. It's so far been the most pleasant surprise of the year for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971022271', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 1518, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 789, 'last_played': 1673569239}
review:
This game is not a Terraria ripoff as many reviewers have stated below. It is much more of a Zelda action RPG style game with Terraria like building and crafting, but only in certain areas of the map. 

There is a main quest and side quests you get from talking to NPCs in towns. Your character does have a skill tree and can progress in crafting, which upgrades their skill in those crafting categories.

I have not encountered many bugs as of writing this review and certainly no game breaking bugs. This game seems pretty stable and well crafted I recommend it to anyone who enjoys action RPGs with some crafting elements.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987839133', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2390, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2390, 'last_played': 1671711677}
review:
This game started out a visually nice, and gameplay-wise relaxing experience.
Something I enjoy greatly.
But after continuing the game, it become apparent that there is little variety of content.
Besides the different looking variations of the functionally exact same items, everything is the same.
The various regions look and work mostly the same, there are only minor differences beside the different materials, and enemies found within.
No new major mechanics or other interesting differences.
Especially the terrain generation, the terrain always looks the same.
I still don't know what is the difference between the plains and the forests in this game, they look basically the same, and you can find the same things in them.

Gameplay mostly consist of resource gathering, crafting, which is quite grind heavy, and questing.
The quest are either fetch quests, or kill everyone in a dungeon types.
But at least there is a story line to follow.

In regards to bugs, most of them ware only minor annoyances at first.
But there were a few cases of some game locations slowing down permanently and controls becoming unresponsive.
No reloading or restarting the game resolved it, and I had to mark the area not to visit again.
And finally, after investing 39 hours into the game, grinding out skills, completing all quests, finding all secrets, etc., my save files got deleted and I can not even attempt to load them from the load menu.

It is heartbreaking to say, but I do not recommend this game.
While it does provide a relaxing, and casual experience; the gameplay is way is too monotone, and drawn out.
And on top of it, there are major bugs, including ones that are game breaking and can result in loosing progression.
But the developers show potential, and maybe they next game will be much better.
