review:
Poco tiempo de juego le metí, pero me encantó. Cuando lo termine pongo la opinión completa, pero creo que vale la pena recomendar el juego por las actualizaciones que han metido recientemente, con el fin de conseguir más popularidad.

En definitiva NO es ni un poco parecido a Terraria en cuanto a jugabilidad, si es lo que pensás al dudar si comprarlo o no xd

Lo único es que está en ingles. Yo lo entiendo pero pierde un poco la magia para el que no al no captar el lore básico; una lástima que no haya nisiquiera un mod no-oficial para parchearlo al idioma español. 
Tampoco lo voy a desechar por eso, pero es algo a tener en cuenta en son de aumentar la cantidad de gente que al menos le da una chance.

review:
Just feels very clunky, the UI, movement, combat, and in general. It's not very fleshed out with items, skills, or building, too. Definitely feels like an alpha and I'm surprised this wasn't in early access.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014313813', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 2966, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1834, 'last_played': 1670173289}
review:
[h1]TLDR; A decent and addictive Terraria-inspired RPG marred by shallow or missing mechanics.[/h1]

You ever play a game and your first thought was, "oh no, this is so jank". Those were my first thoughts and it immediately turned me off from this game. The UI is jank, the text is difficult to read, why are the controls so weird, I can't customise the zoom level, this game is a full release and first impressions were not good. Let's push on, give this game a chance.

Oh, I levelled up a profession. That's cool. I like games that reward me for doing meaningful things. And that's how the game got me. It's discovering the next tier of progression and that "fulfilment". And that's all the game has.

[hr][/hr]

[h1]Here are the problems I've discovered after 30 hours[/h1]

- Combat is unfulfilling, the AI is not there. Enemies run straight for you, they can't navigate simple terrain. They've been programmed with some dodge mechanic but they use it frantically. Enemies don't group up or surround you. Bonus: If you've played Terraria, you already know how to cheese enemies.
- Some skill trees are more potent than others. [spoiler] Playing as a pure ice mage, you can straight up murder everything at range. The ice debuffs make the enemies a joke.[/spoiler]
- Every tileset you visit is just the same. It slopes up and down, there are some enemies, vegetation, domestic animals to tame, NPCs looking for a nice place to live. There are no caverns, nothing to incite exploring. Just dig straight down hope for the best. Walk right, clear the enemies, call it a day and go to another tileset.
- Speaking of those NPCs looking for a place to live, it's either a missing feature and planned for the future. It's in the game but when you take them back to your base, nothing happens. You can recruit farmers, lumberjacks, alchemists and so on but they just stand still. This was the biggest trip for me.
- Base building. Sure, you can have it. But there's not much to it. You land at a tileset that you like? They're all the same. You're just better off building efficiently and not decoratively.
- You can come across "hostile" or faction NPCs that don't like your presence for trespassing. I came across a group of smugglers, couldn't trade with them, I just looted everything not nailed down and left. No aggression towards me.

Those are some of the negatives and I'm sure I'll encounter more. The negatives just compound as you play the game more. If you're like me that loves that "ding" you levelled up something, it will scratch that itch. I'll still be playing this game even with all the negatives. Just be aware that the game is shallow and I would not recommend it to anyone that wants something more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198876037423', 'num_games_owned': 82, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1669876616}
review:
I was actually kinda excited to try this game because the trailer looked promising but was severely let down by the quality of the game. 

Major menu bugs meant I had to restart and then when I finally got it to work the tutorial was laggy and input was delayed. This was not an error on my hardware as I can run Terraria, Starbound and other games of a similar vein perfectly. 

This game looks promising and if it is better optimised I may be interested in playing it but currently I don't think it should have been released beyond beta.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117029224', 'num_games_owned': 339, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 125, 'last_played': 1669841466}
review:
I will start by saying this. This game is not bad. However, I have some thoughts I want to share with whoever reads this.
First of all, the setting, I love it, I am a big fan of fantasy worlds so that's cool. There is a problem though. The game is called realms of magic, but the magic is... meh. There is nothing wrong with it, but idk, after reading the name I expected more interesting spells, maybe with. 
I also really expected quite a bit more of possibilities for roleplay, mainly due to this sentence on the game page 'Explore the open world of the Old Kingdom as a knight or a wizard. Or build a house, plant fruits, invest in livestock… become a farmer… that also sounds nice!' which made me thought the story wouldn't be so thrown down your face, but unfortunately to explore the full map you are forced to do specific quests, which is a bit annoying imo. 
Also, while a talent tree is usually cool, I personally prefer to have some kind of 'teacher' or something to make it have a bit more of sense, though that might just be me.
Lastly, the races. While the one being developed promises for very big changes on how the game is played, the current ones are just a stat change and nothing else. No one gives a shit about your race, or at least no one I found so far so my original thoughts of potentially replaying the game as a different race slowly dwindled until they pretty much died.

Again, don't get me wrong, I like the game, but it is because I like it that I want it to be the best version of itself

author: {'steamid': '76561198075127748', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 704, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1670211954}
review:
The menu bugs are incredibly off-putting, so if someone has found a work-around, please let me know.

The game can't even get the basic menu mechanics right. I am unable select race/gender without the selection screen closing, sending me back to the main menu -- it's human male or nothing, apparently, because I can still select back/next, just not any other race/gender combination -- one time, perhaps totally by accident, I could select between races, but then it stopped working randomly and caused the menu to close, and I have no idea why that would happen. I thought perhaps this was due to mouse/keyboard settings (although I have nothing special set up other than LED's), so I swapped to another keyboard and also tried a controller to no avail. This is when I realized that there is no native controller support. Alas, I haven't even gotten to play the game yet due to my stubborn refusal to play as a human male in a fantasy game which allegedly offers other options.

Update: Restarting my laptop, for whatever reason, caused this bug to disappear. Now I can actually play and update this review, assuming there aren't early-access-level bugs on a fully released game, beyond this unnecessary speed bump which does not even appear in the discussions of known bugs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012221863', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 254, 'playtime_forever': 770, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 626, 'last_played': 1669548284}
review: So, I've waited a while to dive into Realms of Magic and the tldr is that I can only recommend this one if you're looking for a different Starbound-esque game. It's more a middle of the road situation than outright negative/positive, but Steam doesn't do that. The game is fun-ish, but aside from story/mission based areas the different random biomes feel copy-pasted with hardly any variety. Quests aren't exactly engaging, and while building is fun... mining resources is a drag. Since you do need to craft a lot of things to unlock 'cool' building blocks it eats up your time. Only get this one if you can get it at a discount and if you know what you're getting into.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058455973', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 320, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 228, 'last_played': 1708059779}
review:
I'm only just beyond the introduction and in the starter fort town, but what needs to be said if, sadly, coming from a biased perspective, is that THIS sort of thing in gaming is what brings people together en masse.

i bought this game because of another positive review here that compared it to Skyrim. Of course, it should be judged on its own merits, so for that respect, it's got influence from the likes of Dark Souls and Starbound.

The fact there are quests surrounding your doings and the happenings therein is a boon to those seeking a good dopamine mine. People love to whine online about having to "fetch" items for NPCs and - would you believe it? - having to travel outward and KILL a certain amount of things or people, and return with news of it. It's almost as if they're actually growing out of the gamer hobby, and are better suited to casual time wasting? Because last I heard from the realm of REALITY, being tasked with venturing beyond my safe zone to hunter-gather while slaying offending parties sounded like the AWESOME life I've never lived in such olden times as to have grown up alongside.

The, quote, "medieval genre" has it made in spades. If you know what to expect in Skyrim - learning by doing, managing your red (health), green (stamina), and blue (magic) bars, gathering supplies for noteworthy needs, crafting, adopting various character builds, interacting with people in order to advance quests big and small, and gain loot, finding secrets (yes, Skyrim had a "find the secret" system. It's that "relieving music" you hear every time you enter a dungeon room with a nice amount of treasure containers and loose loot strewn about that was conveniently tucked away), exacting dominance upon enemies, and the like, then you'll feel right at home with Realms of Magic. You can expect to walk around gathering wood, food, clothes, armors, weapons, metals, miscellaneous objects, and doing other things. It's doesn't have a 3rd-person perspective, but it's currently achieving exemplary standards through its 2D landscapes.

I don't know enough about the game in-depth for not having played extensively enough, but I can assure you, if you're of the DnD, Skyrim, Dark Souls, Elden Ring, Dragon's Dogma, camp who vividly remembers a childhood of playing in the mud, running through the trees, getting into trouble, and bathing only to get back outdoors and have that innocent childlike fun all over again (as is the case with most fans of wanton medieval fare), then Realms of Magic is for you. Buy it. Sans the lack of controller support currently, it's worth getting used to its control scheme, or mapping the control layout to  a controller if that's your thing just to experience this still-in-development diamond in the rough.

Did I mention that it has good writing? ❤️

author: {'steamid': '76561198036233434', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 22, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1669283676}
review:
This game is definitely made for some people out there, but I'm not one of them. Realms of Magic is a misleading name, because there's not much that's very wondrous about this game's tone. It's more medieval than fantasy, and it has a really kind of gross tone.

Comparisons to Starbound have been made, and that's one of the things that initially made me want to play this, but it's not nearly as interactive. It's also not as robust, and there's not a whole lot of interactivity or destructability. It's comparable to Starbound in only the sense that the boss levels in that are also not very interactive or destructible, but in Starbound, you can do more with those levels and you're more likely to find some item to put in your ship or base.

Controls aren't super tight, and there's no real controller support, which is a shame since the keyboard and mouse don't do a great job. Combat is a chore, and it's not really as free an experience as the listing seems to claim. You are going to be fighting monsters, adventuring, and having basically no agency in your role-playing experience. Because there's not a sense of openness or ability to wander, again compared to something like Starbound, there's no real sense of just leaving the story for a while and doing your own thing. And the story is really awful, not even slightly fun. If you enjoy the garbage fire writing of the Dragon Age series, you might be somewhat amused.

There isn't that much customization for your character, so if you were looking for that, you're going to be disappointed. The pixel art style is fine, but it doesn't really excel here at being charming or quaint. That's in part because of the tone it sets, but it just isn't anything special to me.

This is definitely not worth its regular asking price. If you feel like you need to try it, get it on sale and just jump in. You'll find out soon if you like it or not.

review: So far, this game is ok. In spite of the thumbs up, it's important to note that this game isn't going to be for everyone. If you like crafting and setting up bases and click-heavy combat that doesn't really require any thought, this game might be for you. The environments are repetitive but there's a large amount of underground areas to explore if that's your thing. If you were hoping to roleplay, you might want to look elsewhere, as this game doesn't offer much by way of choice and consequence. I really hope the devs update it soon with some more interesting stuff, because it does get a little boring.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081458014', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4098, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4098, 'last_played': 1667433836}
review:
In short I really enjoyed my time with this game, it does have some faults which I'll go into later but as is it was a fairly relaxing experience.

Some Pro's,
- Levelling system is fun. Farming, Mining, bartering, etc all adds to your characters overall level, so everything feels worth doing.

- I enjoyed the game play loop. Go out, explore, complete quests, gather supplies then come back to base, craft stuff, level up, build up your base, repeat. It was simple but I lost many hours to it. though with this game trying to be open ended, other's may have different experiences.

- well paced early game progression, it was somewhat slow, but as you built yourself up, got better gear, and levelled your skills allowing you to handle enemies a little easier, chop trees and mine faster and so on did feel good.
 
Some con's
- Some mechanics just didn't work. Weapons like daggers and spears have -30% and 10% mana cost but this never worked, I tried a few experiments and never obtained the benefits, potions with the same effects also didn't work. But if gear specified the mana type (frost, Fire, nature, Necromancy) then the mana cost reduction on them would apply, but it seemed there was a Lowest cost cap.

- boring secret loot mid-late game. All the marked map area's had secret chests to find, each zone had special armor, weapons, tool upgrades and skill experience scrolls which were neat but in the mid to late game the tools always seemed worst than the set you had, and the supplies offered were worthless, like I remember a couple secret chests just having sticks. This made finding all the chests feel not worth it.

 - Quests could sometimes be done out of order, on more than one occasion I'd talked to a person and complete what they asked only to complete another persons quest who directs me to the quests I completed for the first guy.

A couple more thing to note, this game is fairly easy, I only died twice in this game, both were to kamikaze sheep, the first death came out of the blue and caught me off guard since no other enemy did this, the second death was me experimenting with how it worked.
Building felt uninspired, you had plenty of blocks which was nice but not all decorations could be placed on tables and the decorations didn't offer a lot to begin with.
NPC's/ village management also felt unpolished. On your travels you could come across villagers looking for a place to live, they basically acted as shops but had no personality or needs.

Honestly with some tweaks I could see this giving similar games like Terraria a fight. But for now it was a fun distraction and has a lot of untapped potential.

author: {'steamid': '76561198213175719', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 143, 'playtime_forever': 1242, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1242, 'last_played': 1663611237}
review: It's Terraria/Runescape, but they forgot to include the fun parts of terraria, Like building freely, Loot that matters, and cool bosses, but they kept the boring old-school parts of runescape and others, like clunky animations, enemies with 1k hp and damage but the IQ of a headless chicken, Too much grind to be fun, 10 different skills but only 3 that matter, and too much useless sidequests. 5/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198364606363', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 145, 'playtime_forever': 141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 141, 'last_played': 1664009090}
review: Realm Of Magic is in need of a major overhaul, the most pertinent criticism I could level at it is that the game is generic, both the narrative elements and mechanics are perfunctory. The game itself is fairly bug ridden, (I've had to start from scratch twice because the game refused to allow me to mine in areas where I should be able to, restarting my playthrough resolved the issue only for it to reoccur). I've had a similar problem with quests, they don't seem to register properly leading to immense frustration. The overall impression is less than satisfying. Hopefully the dev(s) can turn things around, nailing the fundamentals would be a good start.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110581341', 'num_games_owned': 1358, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 6445, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6445, 'last_played': 1665703338}
review:
I loved it, the problems i found were solved with updates. 
8 to 9/10 if you know what to do and get along with the interface and everything

If you gonna go completionist be a goblin or a dwarf for faster progress on some of the harder achievements and other stuff

If not depend on what kind of playstyle you are choosing if you are going melee goblin, human and high elf are good, if you are going magic caster i m not so sure i didnt tried yet but its preety clear from the start when you choose your character

There are at least 5 secrets on the tutorial and you cant come back after ending it, one is on a body that appear below a block if you mine it.

Do husbandry from start and make a good farm early on, also you need to craft and place trellis over fertile ground to plant some things.
Also to to get at least 3 or 4 of each category vendor to your main base that help a lot for faster progression.

I would add to the game replayability for the last boss (partly solved if you save the game before that fight)

Also try to evade having many saves and lots of autosave and quicksave slots, i ended having 1,83 gb on saves at one point and i deleted most of them and reduced the max amount of those in options menu. (i think they go like 20 to 40mb each)

There could be more advice but i think its better to figure it out by playing

author: {'steamid': '76561197980483803', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 2693, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 529, 'last_played': 1664347578}
review:
This title seems to be heavily inspired by Terraria, so here's the one example that sums up the difference of philosophy between the two games: [b]This game has crafting timers.[/b] Everything about this game is slow and seemingly designed to waste your time even though it's an offline single player game and not an MMO. Why? I loved Terraria and didn't mind the combat. This is not that. The game is fine otherwise and maybe I'm missing something but this is just tedious and boring. Not recommended.

Playable orcs and goblins are cool though.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971090444', 'num_games_owned': 1481, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 4295, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3693, 'last_played': 1664847528}
review:
So, the bad, then the good.

It's repetitive, a little grindy, the combat is simple, the AI is moderately dumb, and the dialogue has some off moments. Additionally, some of the quests and area completions might need a google search.

But,

I found it to be a satisfying scrolling platformer with good progression. You can do everything, more or less, how you want. Build a house, hire NPC vendors, max every trade-skill / profession. Run through zones slaying monsters, harvesting resources, and hoarding things until your storage is bursting.

If you want something chill, with good progression, to just sort of autopilot and not take terribly seriously, you'll probably have plenty of fun. I've enjoyed myself. 

I do wish it had better controller support so it would be smoother on the Steam Deck, but it's playable as long as you're not in a rush to get in your chests.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116659954', 'num_games_owned': 520, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 5180, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5050, 'last_played': 1665695794}
review:
[h1] Fun game but no replay value [/h1]
 You can pick races that give different advantages but it doesn't change the story. In quests you are given different dialog options that can change the quest a little but ultimately the story leads to the same end. Most of the time is spend crafting and gathering resources to level up the skills to then craft better equipment.  Over all I liked the game and if it looks like your kind of game get it but unless there is some expansion or big update after you 100% the game you wont comeback to it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020313592', 'num_games_owned': 986, 'num_reviews': 576, 'playtime_forever': 2168, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2168, 'last_played': 1663341357}
review:
[h1]Sum-Up[/h1]
[h3]In-depth analysis further down.[/h3]

[table]
[tr]
[th]🟩 [b]Pros[/b][/th]
[th]🟥 [b]Cons[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]
- Compelling exploration: both handcrafted locations and sandbox areas feature plenty of secrets to discover, different loot types and a diverse enemy roster in each region.

- Great amount of secondary quests that are worth doing in terms of rewards, lore and story. Some of them have multiple choices that may unlock other quests later.

- Solid variety of possible builds, supported by a large number of different weapons and gear. Respec is possible (for a price) if you want to try other builds.

- The art style is pleasant, consistent, and has a high amount of detail in each location.
[/td]
[td]
- Mid to late game balance issues. Even on Hard difficulty, you’ll be too powerful most of the time with equipment congruent to your build.

- The sandbox features are useful just for a handful of secondary quests. Generally they can be ignored as you’ll loot, buy and find all you need regardless.

- Navigation and questing in larger cities prove annoying due to the absence of a local map and many areas or characters looking similar.

- Most bosses and ‘powerful enemies’ don’t feel much different from regular foes except for higher HP and damage. Exception made for the final boss.
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[table]
[tr]
[th]🟨 [b]Bugs & Issues[/b][/th]
[th]🔧 [b]Specs[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]
- Some achievements don’t trigger when the condition is met and remain locked.
- In rare cases, critical NPCs may be permanently in combat. Reload an earlier save to fix.
- If alt-tabbed from Fullscreen, GPU usage spikes to abnormal levels.
[/td]
[td]
- 3900X
- 2080Ti
- 32GB RAM
- SSD
- 1440p
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[table]
[tr]
[td][b]Content & Replay Value:[/b][/td]
[td]It took me 36 hours to complete Realms of Magic (RoM), taking extra time to finish all side quests I could find, find all secrets and build a custom base on Hard difficulty. The content is linear and since there’s a relatively cheap respec to try other builds, I see no reason to replay once finished.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td][b]Is it worth buying?[/b][/td]
[td]Yes. The default price of 16,79€ is excellent for this amount of content and quality. I can recommend buying without discounts.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td][h3]Verdict: Good[/h3]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2548409603]Rating Chart Here[/url][/td]
[td]An interesting ARPG that combines sandbox elements, linear story and handcrafted locations in a clever way. It’s fun and plays out well, however various issues prevent it from being truly great.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2863435926

[h1]In-Depth[/h1]
[h3]Premise, Setting & Writing[/h3]
The Old Kingdom is your run of the mill medieval-era setting, with the addition of high fantasy elements like magic and other races like Orcs, Elves etc. Misery is the norm for most, death all too common, and even darker times are ahead due to war and the resurgence of old magic previously sealed for centuries. Legends foretell the coming of a great hero that will turn the tide of events, thus saving the reign - that indeed would be you.

Overall, the setting well-represents the grim quotidianity of the common folk in such times, and the stark contrasts between the various social classes in a kingdom that is still recovering from previous conflicts, and whose elite is selfish, unscrupulous. Each city, fort, outpost and dungeon is handcrafted with solid attention to detail, always in a style that reflects the region it’s located in, or the social status of its inhabitants. While the graphics may not be much modern, RoM makes up for them with detailed worldbuilding.

There’s an above-average amount of lore and dialogues for an ARPG: other than quest-related ones, those interested may peruse a great amount of books and documents, other than asking NPCs about plenty of topics. All of this is written competently, with a few dialogues that I found particularly clever or amusing, as well. The main story itself is nothing special and feels somewhat rushed in later chapters, but for this genre is more than passable.

[h3]Exploration, Looting & Secrets[/h3]
RoM’s world is divided into tiles each housing a city, dungeon, or plain wilderness. While pre-made locations are ‘protected’ thus immune to your tools and blocks, sandbox areas can be built upon and modified freely. Many areas and whole regions will initially be locked, becoming available only when you either progress the main story enough, or find ten map fragments of that specific region (very hard to come by) - quest-related locations will still be locked in a region unlocked this way, though.

Locally, levels lack a map and always house a number of secrets in the form of shiny containers often placed behind destructible barriers or in particularly obscure locations. These will prove vital to your progression as they often contain powerful gear and other rare items. Generally you’ll be able to freely loot any container, even inside houses, as ‘stealing’ isn’t accounted for - just don’t expect to find great stuff in non-combat areas. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2863055627

[h3]Combat & Progression[/h3]
Fights play out in real time, in an ARPG fashion where stats given by passive abilities, equipped gear and stacked buffs will be pivotal to your success. For this purpose RoM has several ability trees to pick, ranging from four schools of magic to specializations in diverse melee weapon categories, each with their unique active and passive perks and freely multi-classable. Respec is available for a relatively high price, but if you screw up your build it will be there (if you find the right NPC, that is).

Enemies are varied and have a wide range of skills, damage types and attack patterns that will surprise you more than a few times. Sure, some are ‘reskins’ of weaker ones, but always have some additional quirk - it’s a shame ‘powerful enemies’ (mini-bosses) don’t further expand this variety. The combat system expands with passives such as dodge-rolls, magic barriers and more which further the tactical possibilities and flexibility - you won’t need to strategize much though, especially later when most builds inevitably become OP.

[h3]Quests & Dialogues[/h3]
Some NPCs will give you quests of various nature from assassination, investigating an event, to taking to someone and so on. There’s no indication of quest-givers, so talking with everyone is the only way to be sure. Most quests are linear, and will have only one outcome, although a few have different choices that may or may not influence the story ahead (but never in a major way). The dialogue system is nothing elaborate and has no roleplay elements: while some NPCs will react differently based on your race, the options and responses will be the same. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2861885746

[h3]Crafting, Base Building & Farming[/h3]
Sandbox areas will allow building a custom base that can eventually contain farms, animal pens, NPCs that trade for you and also act as Trainers, increasing your profession levels for a high fee. The various jobs level up either that way or by crafting things related to them, for instance Cooking is leveled by crafting food. While on paper this is a nice system, it’s ultimately a marginal feature for the simple fact you’ll find most of what you need by looting enemies, normal containers or trading with merchants, since you’ll soon accumulate vast amounts of money. The farming mechanics are basic, with plants growing without need for care and animals producing goods over time if fed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087785833', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 3623, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3623, 'last_played': 1663524185}
review:
I played all the way through to the end and the review may contain some non-specific spoilers.

TLDR: This is a cozy game that does not challenge or frustrate significantly. It's ideal if you want to explore pretty handcrafted 2d environments looking for secrets, and enjoy leveling up and seeing the next tier of goodies you can craft.

Pros:
This game is ideal for someone who enjoyed Oblivion or Skyrim playing on easy difficulty and enjoys the little hit of dopamine that every level up and progression provides, or someone who plays an MMO casually and is thrilled by reaching a new tier of equipment.
I've spent a lot of hours on Realms of Magic and for the most part I enjoyed them. I found the game to be "cozy." I didn't feel challenged at any point, except challenged to put just a little more time in and grind a few more skill levels before putting it down for the night. 
Overall, this game was able to capture my attention in ways that some other similar 2d titles simply couldn't. In other games for instance, there was never any incentive not to simply tear down NPC areas and use the materials to your own ends. This never feels good to me, It feels cheap and low, but it also feels irrelevant since many games like this generate these structures anyway. Instead, quest areas are protected in this game and look really nice. Additionally, dungeons and other locations are hand-made with secrets lovingly placed, so every single area in the game feels both fun and rewarding to explore. There are guides available to get all the secrets, but once I got a feel for how they were placed and what to look for, I was able to find all of them without a guide. 
If base building is not your cup of tea, don't worry! There are quests in both the mid and late game that unlock complete control of big pre-built places, even including secret chests full of additional crafting stations and materials you can use to make alterations.
If base building IS your cup of tea, the unprotected areas of this game ARE generated. They are all samey, so don't worry about placement too much. The map has marking tools to help you remember where you've put things. Once an unprotected region is cleared out, it's clear. It will not be attacked by monsters, and no new trees/crops will grow unless you plant them yourself. I never got into the base building and late game customization, but I did have fun populating my single house with traders who would re-stock with goods I didn't want to get myself, and enjoyed surrounding my small house with ever-expanding farmland.
You are able to make every kind of workstation you need from the very beginning of the game, and unlocks for these are only aesthetic.
Inventory management is not an issue. Additional inventory spaces can be accessed through 2 different crafting progressions, and I only found myself completely full a couple of times. 
Exploring and progressing in the game, as well as finding secrets, provide you with scrolls which give your character significant experience boosts to different skills, making skill progression a breeze even if you focus on finishing questlines.

Cons:
Polished Games has not, as far as I can tell, released any other games. From what I can find they are a small indy dev in Poland. That makes the name an excellent pun, and a bit of a misnomer, as this game is not exactly polished.
Realms of Magic runs pretty well. I actually find the art direction to be very appealing. The game controls pretty well, but not always perfectly. I struggled early on with sprint jumping, discovering that for a sustained sprint you want to use shift+direction but I found long sprint jumps were only possible by double-tapping the direction button. It was hard to get a feel for how to get my character to move how I wanted, early on. 
This wasn't a lot of trouble because the game is not challenging. I only used a single playthrough, a melee and armor build, and I did scour every region for all of it's secrets before progressing, so that may contribute to my perception. I found most enemies to be reskins of previous encounters with minor tweaks, and was a little surprised when in the last two regions of the game I started seeing units placed strategically to take advantage of ranged abilities. I will say magic looks and feels underwhelming, so perhaps playing a wizard is hard-mode. In my playthrough, I found that the progression system leads you to specialize in just one kind of weapon, and there was never a point at which it felt worthwhile to deviate. My whole playthrough was spent spamming the same never-ending slice-slice-stab sword combo, occasionally using my RMB to block or use another ability. 
The storylines are pretty basic, the same kind of stuff you see in RPGs, and never deviate from expectations. I found the early game to have some light choices in quest resolution in terms of whether to chose diplomacy or violence, but this stops being relevant fast. Only one quest got an honest chuckle out of me, and it's in the first region. My partner played this game as well and ended up with an ending so different I laughed out loud. 
None of the above is a con as much as it is a preamble to say that typos are common in the script, as well as pieces of dialogue that feel clunky. I quickly found that I wasn't getting invested in the story as much as I was just working on the vibe of each region.
The game does not have replay value. There are no significantly branching storylines. As far as I'm aware race and class are mostly irrelevant. If you play thoroughly, you will completely max out your preferred play style well before reaching the final region.
That said, the game is a headache if you want to complete it 100%. Some achievements are bugged. There is an endgame quest that requires you to bring a series of unique, non-quest items (which I sold to get out of my inventory) to an NPC. I wouldn't mind this so bad if it wasn't the only quest of it's kind, making it feel like replay bait. There was no way to restore these without editing the game files. A simple collector NPC that sells copies of these specific items would resolve this. This would be more forgivable if the game didn't have such a casual feel until the very end.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996592038', 'num_games_owned': 265, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2250, 'last_played': 1663281124}
review:
If you like Terraria, you'll probably like this. Great crafting system, fun combat, interesting skill trees.

Could use some improvement on the tutorial and slight pacing adjustments, but overall a great game to throw some hours in.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003123296', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 5935, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5713, 'last_played': 1663377765}
review:
Great Terraria/RPG hybrid. Less clunky than Starbound. OK story-line, but could work on a bit better quest help with some of the more obscure quests. Tutorial could be built out more to explain some of the less-well explained examples, maybe by introducing a town-builder bit or a tradeskill filter by minimum level so that you don't have to scroll through huge lists to try to figure out the most efficient way of leveling.

Other than a few QoL improvements, I feel that Realms of Magic is a well-polished fun game. It would be amazing if multiplayer could be incorporated.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005965931', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 1881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 641, 'last_played': 1663936134}
review:
Thought with the sale and all, this would be a good time killer, a fun little distraction.

Well, here I am, 10 hours later, wondering what else I can do?! There is so much to do! This is my new addiction. I'm serious. Its like Elder Scrolls and Minecraft had a kid that was really into Runescape. Its crazy good and a whole lot of fun. There is just so much to do and I haven't even done all the quests for the first town yet. I'm to busy working on my new home/mine/farm. 

I don't want to put a lot of Cons down yet because I am not sure what is and isn't in the game yet. I feel like I have only scratched the surface. So, I will come back and edit this if things change or I learn the mechanics exists.

1. Not sure if you can fish yet
2. I want to be able to set up in a city and sale my wares. You can make Merchant stalls, just not sure if they are cosmetic only?
3. Family. Come on, we can build a home, a farm and all that. Lets Fable this thing up! Lets  have a partner and kid to work the field. I got things to do.
4. Can we attract NPCs to our little sandbox creations? We can make sign posts and pretty much everything you need to create a town. Taverns and whatever. Will NPCs come hang out? Because if not, they need too. Don't want to spend hours creating a ghost town.
5. Able to attack NPCs. Some of these dudes are asking for it. Maybe at some point.

Anyway, amazing game. Easily an 8/10 for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198403394028', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 6280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2056, 'last_played': 1663987599}
review:
상당히 재밌습니다. 

다양한 종족, 다양한 스토리,  방대한 세계관 

기본 난이도로 하면 스트레스 없이 플레이 가능합니다. 

마을이나 던전의 맵은 기본적으로 시크릿 아이템이 있는 곳 말고는 땅이 안파집니다.

그외에 일반 필드는 맵이 샌드박스 형식이라 
자유롭게 파고 짓고 가능합니다. 

엑트3에 가시면 마녀가 사는곳이 나오는데 
그곳에서 스킬 초기화 가능합니다 금화 10냥 

필드를 돌아다니면 노예로 부릴 만한 
농부나 광부가 있는데 따라오라고 할수있습니다 

나중에 제가 마을이나 집을 건설한다면 어떻게 이용가능한것같은데 아직은 모르겠네요. 

기본적으로 제작, 거래, 채집 등등 다양한 활동이 숙련도 시스템으로 많이 하면 레벨이 오르지만
필드를 돌아다니면 상자에서 나오는 스킬 경험치 스크롤로  무난한게 올라갑니다.

그래도 어느정도 채집과 제작은 해야 잘 올라요. 

가끔 퀘스트 아이템을 모아도 인식이 안되는 경우가 있었는데
하다보니 다시 인식하네요. 

게임이 상당히 짜임새가 좋은 느낌이라 
버그는 없는것 같습니다.


언리얼엔진4 크래쉬가 초반에 많았는데
이것저것 다해봤자 소용없고 
방화벽에 예외 설정해주면 해결됩니다. 

계속 플레이하면서 또 추가하겠습니다.

상당히 저의 취향이라 같이 하는 분들 많이 생기고 번역도 되었으면 합니다.


아쉬운 점 몇가지 적습니다. 

1. 언어   
아직 한글번역이 없어서 스토리나 아이템 등 직관적으로 이해가 어렵습니다. 
물론 천천히 보면 해석은 가능한 수준으로 어려운 단어들은 크게 없지만 
그래도 재미가 반감됩니다. 

2. 드롭 아이템.
이건 좀 애매한데,  좀 사실적으로 컨텐트를 구성한거라면 
사실 엘프를 죽이던 마법사를 죽이던   소지품이  돈이랑 생수 혹은 포션 일수도 있겠지만
이게 게임적으로 본다면 그래도 메인퀘스트나 네임드 몹이라면 
뭔가 그럴싸한 아이템이 드롭이 되야 재밌는데, 
전혀 그런게 없습니다.    그냥 생수 한병..ㅎㅎ  
이걸 보완하는 시스템이 맵마다 시크릿 상자가 3~6개 존재하는데 
거기에 보면 쓸만한 아이템과 스킬 포인트 올리는 재료템이 들어있어서 충당은 되는데.. 
그래도 좀 아쉽다는 말씀. 


3. 위 내용과 비슷한 부분인데, 
마을에 상점을 운영하는 상인들이 있는데.. 
전혀 도움이 안됩니다.
예를 들어서 내가 어떤 가방을 제작하려고 하는데, 
늑대이빨이 좀 부족하다.. 그러면 옆에 상점에서 늑대이빨 정도는 팔아야 하는거 아닙니까 
마을마다 상인이 파는 템이 똑같다는건 ..  아직 제작자가 손대지 않았다는 거겠죠..
업데이트 기다립니다.


4. 액션과 마법이 단조롭습니다. 

게임의 스토리나 내용물은 방대하지만 
그에 비해 케릭터의 액션이나 마법은 상당히 단조롭습니다. 
플레이 시간이 길어질수록 이부분이 지겹게 느껴지네요.


5.부족한 컨텐츠 

마지막 보스를 잡았는데 잡으려고 잡은게 아니라 
그냥 어찌어찌하다가 만나서 잡았습니다.. 

아직 만들지 못한 갑옷들과 아이템들이 있는데
그것들을 만들 이유가 없어짐과 동시에 
더이상 진행할 퀘스트도 없고 

act 1을  클리어한  기분인데, 
게임이  끝났네요. 

처음 종족을 선택하는 화면에는 대륙이 상당히 크게 나왔는데 
나중에 또 업데이트되면 대륙의 다른 곳들도 가보고 싶은데 
아마 힘들겠죠?

그래픽이 2d 라서  맵이 작아보이지만 
실제 크기는 엘더스크롤과 비슷하다고 봅니다.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994469482', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 620, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 31, 'playtime_at_review': 519, 'last_played': 1711584981}
review:
I can understand people relating this game to Skyrim and Terraria. I feel the need to add just a pinch of the old school, eight-bit Nintendo game, Ghosts 'n Goblins too. Just a pinch. 

It's full of crafting, farming, exploring and fighting. The game's deep. It's one of those time-suckers. I'm very glad I bought it. It'll make a great addition to my library.

author: {'steamid': '76561198216174635', 'num_games_owned': 197, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 364, 'last_played': 1662884668}
review: 框架还是很不错的，有意思。不过玩完第一章之后看了看打造栏里面各种等级的材料，感受到一些重复感和肝度。再加上升级实在是有点慢（虽然配置明文放在了data文件夹里面，疑似可以改不过我没试），技能提升太慢新东西不多，新鲜感给我磨没了，然后纯英文读起来还是比较慢，做任务坐牢感略强，就先玩到这里吧。以后有心情再打开玩一玩。

author: {'steamid': '76561198815635643', 'num_games_owned': 146, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 86, 'last_played': 1665200448}

author: {'steamid': '76561198004429095', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 3659, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3659, 'last_played': 1662898496}
review:
An underrated gem of a game! 
There is a lot to enjoy in this game. The exploration, progression, challenge are really great. Building your own little home and decorating it was a fun little side adventure in it's own. The storyline was decent but nothing spectacular. The questing started to feel pretty samey and the combat feels kind of bland. But overall a really great game! I look forward to their next release.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088614379', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1707, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1707, 'last_played': 1662611237}
review:
Whoever did the artwork for this game deserves a medal!

Original concepts on skill builds and an interesting grid map format mixed in with some good old tried and tested runescapesque levels for various crafts and terraria village builder elements.

Heaps of content, progression is very well integrated and rewarding throughout, the sheer variety of gorgeous elements you can craft to construct your own dream base with is endless... Did I mention how juicy the sprite art is?!

Definitely some room for fleshing out. The randomly generated sandbox areas in each region get predictable and dull very fast and the villager recruitment system seems a bit hollow and unfulfilled but you will NOT be disappointed with this game for the great price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081998489', 'num_games_owned': 1458, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 3754, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3754, 'last_played': 1659443986}
review: The main story / game is enjoyable unfortunately there's no real end game or a sandbox mode so once you beat the game there's nothing to do. Would recommend it for one playthrough at least.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048623723', 'num_games_owned': 353, 'num_reviews': 172, 'playtime_forever': 44, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1662632084}
review:
[h1]Too Clunky[/h1]

As you can see up there, I only played this for ~45 minutes. That is because, after my initial try-out, I didn't really feel like coming back to it, and going a little further would likely blow my refund-window.

And that, in turn, is mainly because Realms of Magic's combat doesn't feel right.


[u][b]The basics:[/b][/u]
This game is a combat-focused Terraria-like.

You mine, craft stuff, build a base (I [i]assume[/i] you do, because after the tutorial and a series of quick quests, I didn't get to that part in 45 minutes), and fight enemies.

Realms of Magic lets you move from one world location to another, on a map; it has an extensive skill tree, which is a great thing (sorely missed in Terraria and others of the kind, IMO); and skills that you need to level up such as Blacksmithing and Alchemy.

This all sounds great, at first. But, like I said, the combat ruins it.


[u][b]The combat:[/b][/u]
For starters, you cannot run opposite to the direction your character is facing. If you try, he just [i]walks[/i] backwards. If you are moving right, and then you want to run [i]left[/i], you need to move your mouse's pointer to the left side of the screen, turning your character around, [i]before[/i] pressing Shift.

That's annoying, and takes a bite out of your mobility, making your character frequently feel unresponsive.

You also attack a little too slowly. And the worst of all: you have a stamina bar that is drained with each attack. The one time, in my limited experience with the game, when I ran into 2 enemies at once, I had to kill one then stop and stare at my screen for some 15s, while my stamina bar recovered, before being able to kill the second enemy. So... imagine how horrible it must be when you have to kill 3 of them. Or 20.

Jumping feels a little weird. I can't pinpoint exactly why, but it does. Even if it doesn't to [i]you[/i], everything points to this [i]not[/i] being a game in which jumping is used in combat. So, dodging doesn't seem to be a thing here either -- you just move back and forth, block, attack, wait for your stamina to recover, repeat.

That's boring.

Finally [i]and[/i] least: you have melee weapons and magic in the game. But no ranged weapons. I decided to be an Elf, and intended to become an archer but... that's not an option. I assume they didn't implement archery because there's no dodging or flying/jumping enemies, so ranged combat would make things too easy for the player. (I don't know how magic works, I didn't get to try it; I assume you shoot it, but only straight left or right.

With crappy combat mechanics, the best asset of Realms of Magic -- its skill tree -- is pretty much wasted.


[u][b]Other issues:[/b][/u]
You need to change between Build and Combat mode. That's an unnecessary annoyance which every other Terraria-like game makes do without.

The graphics are fine, but I'm not particularly fond of the character animations, at least not for this type of game.

Your Backpack and Character screens are separated, while they could have been joined. Needing to have two different pop-up screens open to equip your character is always a bit of a drag.


[u][b]In short:[/b][/u]
The game feels generally clunky, in particular the character movement and combat.

In 45 minutes, I didn't even get to [i]start[/i] building a base, which means that, if you want to go into that, and be able to give this game a serious go, you'll very likely end up losing your refund window. (And I still believe you'd want to refund it, an hour later).

They had some good ideas here, but the execution leaves much to be desired. With a severely lacking combat system, the whole thing just becomes rather purposeless and boring.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062969833', 'num_games_owned': 286, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1662429637}
review:
Magic is underwhelming. 

In a game called realms of magic I was surprised to find that magic honestly sucks! I got to around level 9 and Summoning magic is near useless. They often die before dealing any meaningful damage. For the mana cost as well its crazy. Direct damage magic is just plain weak or lacks range. Either way enemies I would spend 30 seconds on with default melee attacks took nearly 5 minutes with magic. 

Its nearly a great game but doesn't encourage players to actually use magic. It gets formulaic and grindy since magic is so slow. Combat in general is just unreasonably slow.

Why do we have huge towns that I need 30 stamina bars to cross the town? I don't know.

Just a lot of little things make this what otherwise was nearly I diamond in the rough not worth it in my opinion.

Also new update allows you to respec your talent points but it comes way too late into the game. Please make this a feature you can access without a area specific NPC.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029513448', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 97, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 86, 'last_played': 1662400473}
review:
It's a game that is honestly too steeped in Survival Crafting Minecraft culture to be its own game. The tutorial is very much not comprehensive, it's a guy who just tells you "Go here, do this" a few times before story happens and you're on your own. 

You spend the first hour or so of the game gathering resources and leveling up your various gathering skills, as well as your character. After you level up, you get a talent point. This talent point is not something you spend on crafting, gathering, or exploration based skills, but rather, combat and elemental magic, things you have not been making heavy use of at the beginning. Was hoping to invest my first talent point in any kind of mining skill to make mining and gathering easier, but no such skill or even skill tree exists. It's weapons, combat, and elemental magic only. That's what you spend your talent points on after making a house and bed. 

It also has the problem of way, way too many crafting stations. It is tedious anti-fun to have to go from crafting station to crafting station just to make a door. The first station you make offers the recipe of a door, but you can't make a door without a furnace and an anvil because it requires Nails, and no one will tell you that those are the two crafting stations needed to make Nails, only that the door requires Nails and you have to guess where to get it. 

This game has far too great of an expectation of the player and their knowledge base of other survival crafting games to really be its own game. This game offers very little beyond being terraria/starbound with level ups and skill trees.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014231156', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1781, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1781, 'last_played': 1662385696}
review:
Decent framework of a game here and there's definitely potential.
The game loop however is boring and repetitive and game areas are extremely boring copy pastes of the same 5 or 6 biomes. Each biome is basically a reskin of the previous one with almost no new gameplay or tactical elements. 

At anything more than £10 this game is ripping you off at the moment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078993974', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 2861, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1376, 'last_played': 1662999666}
review:
Hidden Gem- 22hrs in nowhere near endgame.
 
Its a addictive open world building crafting RPG with story, factions, quests and characters.

 Hand crafted maps for towns/dungeons/quest locations and procedural maps where you can build for wilderness, works well and makes the world feel alive and moving unlike other games that are procedural and feel bland and soulless.

Quests/story are mostly good, well enough written to be interesting - there are simple fetch quests too but not too annoying and they add some flavor/context to each town.

The wilderness locations are a bit boring though - when you dig down its pretty much the same all the way down except the bottom which is very un-impressive, I was expecting some kind of terrain change or to find some interesting structures or tougher foes as I dug down..... still a really fun game that just stood out as under developed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198430178408', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 5294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 699, 'last_played': 1662466425}
review: It's like Terraria with music reminiscent of Skyrim. There are protected areas with secrets to find and quests to find from talking to NPCs. Most of the map is unprotected areas, where you can build and gather freely. If you wander enough you can find wandering NPCs that will follow you to your base if you ask them to. All around decent game, I'm excited to see where it goes after some more updates.

author: {'steamid': '76561198353611986', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2303, 'last_played': 1661665273}
review: So. I have a good amount of hours in this game so I think that I have a good handle on it. It is a mixture of skyrim and starbound. With the gameplay of starbound and the atmosphere of skyrim. I ground this game so that I could get all of the achievements and I have to say that it is very fun. The grammatical errors in some of the text, enemies, and chests not spawn if you play for too long causing you to restart the game from the menu, and other stuff like that. author: {'steamid': '76561198052313621', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 1220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1165, 'last_played': 1698096702}
review:
It's like Starbound without the space stuff, with an overworld map view with a grid of tons of other squares you can visit, offering another explorable map with stuff to fight, find, mine and gather.

My favourite thing about it is the customisation. You can vary your playstyle quite a bit by making your racial choice in the character creator, and there is a slider bar for difficulty - enemy HP and enemy DMG. You can play it like Dark Souls if you want. Or you could play it like Terraria on easy mode. The choice is yours and I absolutely love that and wish more games would have this feature. Even just to negate the amount of reviews people leave complaining about a game's difficulty. 

You can put in all the deathtrap mechanics you want to a game, so long as you give people the opportunity to walk through it all with plot armour on at the flick of a switch, then who is going to complain exactly?

There are some light story elements, some small time quests and mysteries to uncover, but it's nothing insane, the premise seems to be on building a base and crafting stuff, as the world map offers like a thousand different areas or something like that, once explored.

The problem I found was the stuff to do in those biomes. Other than the quests, and the usual gameplay loop found in these games of finding fighting looting etc, there simply isn't much to do. You can find loot, sell it in town and buy some other stuff like in a more traditional RPG, like in Starbound, but you can't really buy anything as interesting. 

There aren't any mounts that I've seen and the usefulness of items sold quickly became nil next to what I could craft. It doesn't feel like a lot of time is given to find the balance between grinding and the crafting system and the prior feels pretty useless. 

Clothes sets or anything would be cool to buy off them. Maybe have a little relationship quest system with each townsfolk  NPC and have them sell unique little inventories that unlock once you're friends with them? It'd help longevity. At the moment once you've bought a few things and done the few quests there's really no reason to visit towns.

And in the biomes themselves I found there weren't any hidden things or anything interesting within the procedural creation. No random little things that are out of the ordinary, compared to Starbound. It has had years of development though, compared to this, so perhaps it's unfair to compare them in regards to content.

The tailored zones are full of interesting little hidden areas though and are usually very well done. The hidden things are, if you don't upgrade beyond the quest's particular area, a worthy upgrade to what you have at the time. There are a few different sets of armour but I would have liked to see way random loot given the nature of the game's explorable map.

One thing I will nitpick on is the way buildings are done in this game. It has this Starbound awkwardness with the architecture which is very obvious when you try to make public / open areas like streets and shops.

Just have the lower part of the building only visible if you open the door and enter it. Which is on the front. So you'd have the building just looking like... a building, from the front, and when you go inside, THEN it transitions to the interior that you can interact with, with the npcs inside or the shop or whatever. 

I'm pretty sure this is how you used to do this in old NES RPGs but for some reason it is STILL NOT DONE in these games. Which more and more, appear to be paying homage to those games. With new technology in a game engine like this, you could up the way they used to do it by not having a loading screen once you enter, just phase the opening away and reveal the interior.

Other than that minor gripe, I really enjoy the game. I am excited to see the dev is still updating it, the last update that adds settlers and people you can find in the randomly generated zones that can join your base and sell stuff. And you can equip them gear. But I really would hope for more stuff to fight... maybe bandit raids on your built homes or towns to spice things up a bit. Random wolf attacks if you choose to keep animals so you have to keep your flock safe.

An awesome feature would be to add the ability to have these settlers be somewhat randomised, not vendors all the time, and instead like a companion. Who could live in a building you set, sure, could become a vendor that you'd like to have there for no reason, sure, but could also follow you. 

You could meet a really tough human dude on the road being attacked by bandits, befriend him, set him up with some awesome armour, and tell him to guard your base. Instead of just having a copy of a system from Terraria, and a less sense making system than Starbounds. A more Conan Exiles approach to npcs would be better. Especially seeing as it's glaringly quite strange to me these days that all these vendors are just here for.... me. My town... like I'm some weird tyrannical overlord or something. Some derranged cult leader millionaire.

No one ever visits our towns to just buy things or hang out, stay temporarily, drink at the bars, do they? It's all AWFULLY barren. That'd be a neat thing to add, too.

Anyway if you were to get that kind of companion system going and have varied, cool, sometimes random or rare stuff to fight like Demonic portals that rarely spawn in underground dungeons on some overworld maps, with Demons and a Demon Lord boss to fight that is really tough... with varied loot... then this game would really be something.

But right now it sits comfortably alongside other decent games like this, with enough of its own quirk to set it apart on the store shelf.

Axe throw OP

author: {'steamid': '76561198030392111', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 1097, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 395, 'last_played': 1660824809}
review:
i am amazed bt the reviews that compare this title with terraria and hsi spiritual sci fi son starbound

a quick comparison will immediately show that in both game the crafting/base building area is way more important
i am at the end of act two and i still have to understand how exactly this whole crafting work
there are on the map tiles that are "protected" from player modification and these are the hub and quest areas like cities or dungeons
i begin to suspect that all the other tiles (that in my mind where simply decoratives on the map) are actually sandbox location
that or i have yet to encounter a specific place on the map that is unprotected
i suspect that is the first of the 2 theories because i am stuck with delievering seeds of specific plants to a faction and i am nowhere near to have the amount required to complete the quest from "scripted locations" (the only one i have yet found)
from what little news i have found in internet it seems that i have to grind them in sandbox locations also because differently from the seeds of the first area the seeds of the second area are no found into a merchant inventory or if they are i have yet to identify the merchant in question

not only that but i hav yet to understand exactly how and whre to cut a tree because the game do an horrible job in explaining his mechanics and the only tree i have found are in scrioted not modificable locations

terraria and starbound are true sandbox games
you can farm mine and build almost in any location
in this game no
it seems that there are two games mashed togher 
a rpg with a storyline
and a crafting/base building game
but this game are separate and don't comunicate with each other efficiently

from what i have seen of the rpg part it is not bad at all
(expet platforming) that sucks badly especially because the inner workings of the sprint function (that half of the times doesn't work even with full stamina bar) is still debated among scientist and a profound mistery to even its original creator

jokes aside the rpg part is entertaining and combined with the pixel art a good experience so far
te problem of this game is that it hopes to be much much more but it seems that the developers divided themselves into two team
one for the rpg and one for the sandbox
they created two separte game and then at the end the put the two halves togher

it has potential but it need a good calibration better implementation of the sandbox part and a general polish

miles behind terraria or even starbound as sandbox
a pretty solid rpg in pixel art that can easily absorb a few hours of your time in exchange of a relaxed exploration as rpg

also don't expect terraria level of fighting
way more basic

review: Love the game...until the COINS for WORDS mission. It is bugged, i talked to every guard and they took my money. Did not get the option to continue the quest and when i spoke to the guards again, and had 50 gold....AGAIN they took it a second time. I cant continue and im NOT starting over for it to happen a second time. guess its time to move on to something else.
developer_response: Issue with quest Coins for Words is now fixed in version 1.1.0.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990107032', 'num_games_owned': 588, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 6355, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6225, 'last_played': 1660237764}
review: Quite fun!  I managed to finish all the quests and secrets at level 48 and got most the achievements (except a couple gathering achievements and getting to level 50) in a bit over 100 hours.   Not really wanting to keep playing   just to get the last achievements in a slog.  (If I played over would probably try a goblin necromancer since both are so hated in the game)  Game was fun and scratched the Terraria itch but with more questing  which I loved.   Some glitches here and there but none were game breaking for me (well I did have to replay a couple areas as there were some glitches that would break a quest but they didn't happen consistently so the replay of small portion was ok).  The pre-built bases meant I spent less time building my own town/castle which could have been an even bigger time sink.  Good value for the money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198393585789', 'num_games_owned': 240, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 3197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3106, 'last_played': 1701531276}

author: {'steamid': '76561197972991191', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3754, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2756, 'last_played': 1702486394}
review: its pretty good. nothing really special though.  the perlin noise map for generation is pretty much as basic as it gets, no advanced generation, or water, or special areas inside of the generated maps.  i find the entire digging part, to be somewhat of a main part of the game, and yet, nearly a waste of time, since you can accomplish everything easier without digging at all.  encounter wise only really has a couple different types, Tough wild animal, pack of animals, group of NPCs,  tough NPC.  so its fairly predictable.  the crafting/selling system is broken AF too.  without leaving my base, i can level 10 times faster than any quest or mission. and make far more money than i would ever need, i started a new game the other day and  by the time i was level 10 i had nearly 500 gold. but overall its still pretty decent of a game, i would hope future patches and content would push this game farther

author: {'steamid': '76561199215734427', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1628, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1617, 'last_played': 1660084073}
review: after playing realms of magic for at least 15 hrs, i get to the mission COINS FOR WORDS, and find a game breaking bug.  I speak to all the soldiers that the mission requires, yet the mission does not end.  Went back several times to make sure i had completed all tasks and yet no mission ending. Being a main mission it is needed to continue the game.  it was a great grind for 15 hrs. and the game was quite enjoyable.  yet, now i will never know the end game.
developer_response: Issue with quest Coins for Words is now fixed in version 1.1.0.

review:
Absolutely love, enjoy and recommend this game!!! I'm 47 hours in and I'm just about half way in!! I mean, I've spent and taken my time on mining, building, exploring and all that. I'm sure someone rushing could finish in 10-20 hours, but there's so much to do why rush? 

It's like a mix of Terraria and Minecraft and some other survival games you may know. There's a lot of skills/trees you can invest in and you can invest in a mix of all of them if you so choose to!!

review:
Terraria + Skyrim + dunkler Humor = Realms of Magic, 

das gute oder fordernden ist das es noch kein ausgebautes Wiki gibt in dem man alles nachlesen kann wenn man zu faul ist. 

So musste ich alles selbst erkunden, ein 16 Seitiges Buch úber die Religion der alten Götter lesen und mir einprägen für ein rätsel, habe einer Prinzessin geholfen einen Mann zu töten weil sie eine Vergewaltigung vorgetäuscht hat und nebenbei unendliche Lacher erlebt. 
für das Geld kann man nichts falsch machen und wer 100% erreichen will hat etliche Stunden zu investieren ! :) 

9,8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198014428631', 'num_games_owned': 278, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 4231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3210, 'last_played': 1697458123}
review:
content price ratio (2/5)
you get starbound/terraria kinda. however, if compared, its even less content than alpha version starbound.
playtime first run until final boss? less than 15h.
replayability? moderate.
if you find it for 5€ give it a shot :) however for current price n content its a skip.

the world.
medieval/fanatasy setting. There is a world map divided into tiles. about 80% of these tiles can be visited and explored.
the remaining 20% are ocean or mountains which can not. About 70 of these tiles are handcrafted dungeons and towns. and they are rly great designed. here is were the game rly shines.
each of these prebuld maps comes with secrets to discover and minibosses to slay.
all the other tiles are sandbox maps. and those are kinda disapointing, since they basicly all look the same. there are no computer generated towns or dungeons as starbound has.

narrative and progression.
this is where the game shine above starbound, you are not forced to follow the narrative.
there are 2 ways to unlock new biomes and there for new tiers. either finish the storyline of a biome. or find 10 map pieces and craft the map of the next area.
the quest design is rather boring and once you reach the second biom you will hate the game. since you get 3 different quest each asking for certain plant seeds. which have a super low droprate and can not be obtain in any other way.
so yea i was glad to find out bout the map pieces. their drop rate how ever is way too high. you basicly go to 1 sandbox map. dig down for 10min, killing stuff opening chests and you will have the 10 map pieces requiered.
this means i did the questline for biome 1 and 2. skipped all quests of biome 3-6 and only did the quests of the final area since you have to.

difficulty.
the game is overall to easy. playing as a gnome, which is supposed to be the hardcore class (less health n stamina) becomes mandatory if you want to stick to the game.
thing is this game defines your character by the skilltree and the gear you loot. the combat-skilltree provides way too much armor and stamina cost reduction.
the gear is so stupidly strong you wont ever need to drink a potion biome 3+. since the amount of armor health/stamina/mana recovery on armor is just ridiculous.

skills and leveling.
there are 7 skilltrees?!
heavy duty weapons: sword, axe, mace, / fast weapons: dagger n spear / combat: passive stuff like armor n stamina / fire, ice, nature and necromancy
all schools of magic offer an aimed ranged atk, nature n necromancy summon minion as well.
without grinding to much you will be between lv40-50 by the endof the game, which is enough to max out 2.5 of these skilltrees.
yet skillpoints can also be crafted by looting cettain orbs. (rly unnecessary feature imho)
noticed sth? no ranged combat other than magic. no bow, no crossbow, no slingshot, no siege weapons not even as decoration.

construction complexity.
alot of basic things missing. 
- no liquids at all. no ponds, no sewage, no poison, ... no moat! hey i would like to build a d*** castle!
- no block functions. no slippery, no sticky, no need to water soil, no oil to spread fire. nothing.
- no craftable/placeable traps. there are spikes, flamesthrowers etc in dungeons but you re not allow to use any of these.
recipes are kept very simple and with each new tier you only replace ingredients.
believe it or not your main ingredient will be poop. so get chicken asap. :)

addiction factor. low.
- no multiplayer not even local coop.
- no reason to replay the game since races literly have no impact ( excluding gnome ) and even tho quests often have 2 approaches,
by the end of the day the choice doesnt matter at all.
- there is almost no reason to build a farm or craft own weaons/armor. thing is you find way to much stuff during dungeons or exploration.
crafted armor is the best in game yet only on the very last tier, and only about 2% better than the lootable sets.

fun factor?
dialoge are writen nicly n with some slapstick.
some npc names are just way too fitting like that male prostitute by the name of typhus.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082335341', 'num_games_owned': 213, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2092, 'last_played': 1660440548}
review:
[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*]The story is good
[*]The gameplay is fun overall
[*]Crafting is well done (akin to a simplified Terraria)
[*]Nice music
[*]Excellent level design in the "Locked" or non-Sandbox zones
[*]Looking for secrets is just easy enough to not be tedious and just hard enough to be fun
[*]Devs are very active in Discussions and Discord and responsive
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*]Crafting makes loot and quest rewards obsolete
[*]"Unlocked" or Sandbox levels are repetitive and boring
[*]Gameplay can be too easy, especially with Sorcery based builds
[*]A lot spelling errors
[*]Currently there is little to no replay value
[*]Choices don't actually matter (they affect quest rewards in minor ways, but as mentioned above, those are easily made obsolete)
[/list]

review: I would say if on sale maybe try it.. At the time I am writing this I have 18 hours in, and in that time I see that it goes like this. Start out weak, go somewhere random and mine and loot, become powerful, go to next zone and suck again, and repeat over and over. I did have some fun but like I can tell this is just a pointless grindfest so I will probably move on to the next game. Also if the Devs look at this, I have a suggestion. Add hotkeys to instantly use skills. Maybe I missed that but I found it super annoying and dated to have to scroll through and pick my spell to cast..

review:
I'll try to write more on this later, but I'm too busy playing it right now.

This game has so many different ways to play it, you're sure to find one that appeals to you.  It is absolutely worth the price of admission in its complete 1.0 release state, and I am so excited to see where it goes from here.

Don't mistake it for a Terraria or Starbound clone -- it is its own animal, and thank goodness for that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083014327', 'num_games_owned': 632, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 7455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6888, 'last_played': 1677611453}
review:
Это были славные 100+ часов. Если говорить коротко, то Realms of Magic представляет собой компиляцию Террарии, Стардью и сюжетного приключенческого РПГ.

Как говорили выше - хороший баланс между битвами, фармом и квестингом, но есть одна проблема: ты сам можешь стать виной своего затыка в игре. Например я, после завершения третьей главы сюжета просто ушёл в фарм и постройку городов и двинулся дальше когда достиг 100ые уровни почти во всех профессиях. Есть недочёты и недоделки, немного багов, однако в целом игра заслуживает твёрдых 11/10, магия на кончиках пальцев.

Кстати, очень не хватает стоек для демонстрации собранной брони и оружия.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991202833', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 764, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 584, 'last_played': 1659498983}
review:
I'd use a "neutral" response if I could! Am I having fun? Yes. Will I keep playing? Yes. But would I recommend this? No, I'd suggest to play Starbound instead, if you could only pick one game. The more I play, the more I think "I want to go play Starbound" because this plays very very much like that, with a fantasy reskin, and yet falls short of my actual Starbound experience. The progression of crafting and materials is super similar, the movement of characters and combat is super similar, the story is communicated in walls of text in dialogue boxes rather than slightly more engaging cut-scenes...

Honestly the most jarring part may be the beautiful splash screen and intro movie art that gives me vibes of Darkest Dungeon, but that doesn't coordinate with the in-game sprites at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988487717', 'num_games_owned': 478, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1197, 'last_played': 1659478793}

author: {'steamid': '76561197999259031', 'num_games_owned': 413, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 404, 'last_played': 1659151310}
review:
Its flaws don't quite overtake its charm, unfortunately. 

PROS:
-- The art is nice
-- crafting good
-- good variety of decorations
-- cool fantasy races + lots of differentiation 
-- premade areas look cool + made of achievable materials
-- can rescue NPCs and have them move in with you


CONS:
-- almost uniformly bad dialog. poorly translated or in need of editing?
-- repetitive combat (no ranged weapons)
-- harvesting too slow / not enough resources (especially trees)
-- rewards from exploring (chests) random and underwhelming
-- NO MULTIPLAYER
-- inventory / ui shenanigans
-- stamina bar too small / sprinting too draining / too slow 
-- not enough ranged options
-- the NPCs you rescue just stand there and sell you things
-- can't stack chests or crates, bottles and goblets can't be placed
-- minimal combat experience for fighting
-- repetitive random generated environments
-- few enemy types


NEUTRAL:
-- deep talent tree but shallow selection of abilities
-- let me harvest + move around those glowing mushrooms and other decorative elements

There's a good foundation here, and I'd love to come back and play some more after a couple of updates.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052168721', 'num_games_owned': 128, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2593, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1973, 'last_played': 1659368542}
review:
24+ hours within the last few days on a game that was impulse bought. 

Highly addictive, definitely recommended. 

You get to choose what magic and weapons to use; crafting system is huge; lots of questing that feels much better than fetch quests. 

I bought this game without any prior knowledge of it and love it. 

Only downside is that you can't find much on Google about it if you have any questions. 

Encountered only 1 possible bug since playing and I'm not even sure if it's a bug yet; could be me missing something. All in all its definitely worth purchase price.
